Story: Austrian fashionista, Bruno wants to become world famous. And the only way he can do so is by becoming famous in America. He travels to Los Angeles and tries any and everything to grab headlines, even an attempt to turn straight from gay...

Movie Review: Not so long ago, it was the Kazhakistan simpleton, Borat who had you in splits with his exploits in America. This time, it's the Austrian, Bruno who gives you some risque rocking moments as he chases his dreams -- once again in the USA -- to become the biggest German superstar, after Hitler! And like Borat, this one too is wild and wicked, poking fun at any and everything that's making news in the celeb obsessed world that throbs in the brightly lit boulevards of LA.

So, you have Bruno auditioning in the sundry studios of Hollywood to make it big as a film or TV star. As he himself says, he wants to be the biggest 'gay hero after Arnold Schwarzeneggar.' Ha! But despite displaying all his bigness, he doesn't get a break. So, he chooses to go the Brangelina-Madonna way and begins to look for causes. Global warming is too iffy. Everyone's already supporting Darfur, and there isn't any
Dar-five, he opines and opts for orchestrating peace in the Middle East. He does manage to bring the Israelis and the Palestinians on the negotiating table but gets totally confused between Hamas and humus. What's next? `Black gold' from Africa, he exults and ends up adopting a baby who is summarily snatched from him when the Child Welfare department discovers the toddler is a jolly by-stander at Bruno's adult parties. Eventually, there's only one way to get famous: get straight. And Bruno tries some pulpit talk too. But you'll really have to watch the film to watch if it works...

The film may not be as uproarious as Borat: Cultural Learnings of America to Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan, but it does give you some rollicking moments with Sacha Baron Cohen unleashing his manic energy once again. Enjoy, the adult way.

Story: The film is a biopic on the life and times of Michael Jerome Oher, the American footballer who played for the Baltimore Ravens of the National Football League. Oher's story is essentially an inspiring tale of racist harmony, where a Memphis high society white woman, Leigh
Ann Tuohy, picked up a homeless, hungry and lonely Oher from the streets and brought him into her home, her heart and her family. The rest is history...She not only sent the black boy to college, but ensured he found a place amongst America's foot balling heroes.

Movie Review: For all those who have been bothered by the racist overtones of Avatar, The Blind Side might be even more provocative. Because, here is a story that completely reiterates the myth of the white man -- and woman -- being the saviour of the impoverished, crime-infested, driftless black community. In fact, the film even has one of the characters pitching this paramount question to the benevolent Mrs Tuohy (Sandra Bullock) who wants to legally adopt the abandoned black boy, Big Mikey (Quinton Aaron). So, is this something to do with white guilt, huh? Needless to say, the lady brushes aside this uncomfortable question with a `shame on you!'.

Whether The Blind Side has racist overtones is debatable and left for the theorists. As a piece of cinema, the film works and works quite well, providing Sandra Bullock a role that got her her first Golden Globe and might just end up getting her the Oscar too. As Leigh Tuohy, she's compelling and riveting with her firm resolve to provide a better life for the emotionally challenged 18-year-old who has been on the roads, ever since his mother became a junkie and his father abandoned the family of eight siblings. Needless to say, she's the head of her family too and undoubtedly wears the pants, putting everyone and everything in place, albeit with the support and love of her husband who believes she's truly the best.

Watch Bullock mother the teen who is twice her size, read him bedtime stories of Ferdinand, the gentle giant bull, teach him how to tackle his opponents on the football field and see how she bullies all and sundry, for the well-being of her extended family...Truly, a power-packed performance that makes you sit up and cheer for this erstwhile cheerleader.

Story: A serial killer makes his kill in the guise of a stepfather who breaks the stereotype with his seeming goodness. This time, he infiltrates the family of a divorced mother of three by pretending to be in love with her. But before he can execute his evil plan, he must contend with her teenage son who has just returned from military school.

Movie Review: The Stepfather may have a run-of-the-mill story of a scheming psychopath who cleans up entire families to the soundtrack of Silent Night, but there are enough edgy sequences to keep you glued to your seats. So what if you are always one step ahead of the proceedings, you do get your thrills and chills with every creak in the wood, every jump cut, every surreptitious move as step dad David meticulously plans his murders.

And what's really paisa vasool is the picture of perfection he tries to paint to hoodwink the new gullible family he meets in the mall. At cosy family dinners, he tries to overwhelm them with little sermons on the importance of family, while at night he carries on his mean business in the basement. And anybody who dares to come in his way is conveniently done away with, be it the inquisitive neighbour who discovers on the internet that he actually looks like someone on America's Most Wanted list. Or the real daddy who dares to delve into his antecedents and must necessarily end up in the cold storage.

For those who like to keep their popcorn crunchy, The Stepfather is adequate time-pass.

Story: Max, an imaginative tween, isn't too happy at home. Nobody, neither his teen sister nor his single mother, seem to have the time for him. On one such lonely night, having been punished by his mom, he conjures up a friendly world, peopled by friendly wild creatures...

Movie review: Can we make this mandatory viewing please for a generation of digi-kids who seem to have forgotten the outdoors completely in their obsession with all things tech? Young Max and his wild musings might just be the perfect antidote for Wii kids who are being insidiously weaned away from all things bright and beautiful, all creatures great and small....

Based on Maurice Sendak's 1963 kid's classic which reportedly had just nine sentences, the film is a visual parable on the importance of love, creativity, imagination, family, warmth -- and the wild outdoors -- for a wholesome childhood. Stuff that you can hardly dream of getting from your play station, the iPod, MySpace, malls, MacDonalds or mobiles.

Feeling somewhat neglected by his family, young Max throws a tantrum when his mum's boyfriend stops over for dinner. An angry mom sends him off to bed without dinner and the rest is a riot of imagination. Max runs away on a tiny boat to an island inhabited by strange, oversized creatures. He declares himself king and builds a surrogate family where everybody sleeps in `a real pile'. But soon familial differences set in here too and Max begins to miss his real family. However, he can't return before he sets things right in his newfound kingdom, can he?

This one's truly for family viewing, specially if you have digi-kids.

Story: The United States of America has metamorphosed into the United States of Zombies. Young Columbus wants to make his way to his hometown in Ohio, across this dangerous wasteland, overrun by the undead. Naturally, he needs help: Talahassee, the sharp-shooting zombie killer.

Movie Review: This one's actually a zany little comedy that packs in so much fun, it makes you literally squeal in places. Of course, you begin expecting a run-of-the-mill C-grade Hollywood horror flick, but soon realise there's more bang for your buck in these crazy encounters with post mad cow disease humans who `have the munchies' and just love to sink their teeth in a `manwich'.

Story: A montage of 10 episodic stories, the film was designed as a tribute to the spirit of New York after 9/11. Each episode has been shot by a different director over a period of two days and is eight-minute long.

Movie Review: So what's your favourite New Yorkism? Multi-culturalism, pub culture, smoking on the side-walks, friendly cabbie rides, night-outs with strangers, no-strings-attached sensual encounters, absolute anonymity, endless opportunity, Broadway binging, Central Park strolling, skyscraper gazing, Fifth Avenue ambling, Brooklyn Bridging, Village hopping, day dreaming, night riding....New York, I Love You offers you all this and so much more; sometimes through a vibrant palette of deft strokes and succinct characters and sometimes in somewhat pallid form. Truly, this brain child of producer Emmanuel Benbihy who began with the Parisian ode, Paris Je t'Aime and proposes to make similar `I Love You' films on Rio, Shanghai, Mumbai and Jerusalem, is a mixed bag. Understandably, everyone is going to have their personal favourites.

But the one that truly stand out is Shekhar Kapoor's enigmatic little analysis of suicide and the city, where Julie Christie, an erstwhile opera singer, checks in on the top floor of her favourite Manhattan hotel and encounters a friendly bellhop, Shia LaBeouf. The film, written by the late Anthony Minghella, is sheer visual poetry, with its white interiors and its hazy outlines. Both Shia and Christie are riveting.

The two other stunners include Brett Ratner's funky coming-of-age prom night date story between high schooler Anton Yelchin and teenage method actress Olivia Thirlby and Joshua Marston's tribute to growing old in Manhattan. In this delightful eight-minute feature, a wizened Eli Wallach and his elderly wife Cloris Leachman celebrate their 63rd marriage anniversary on Coney Island, like every other year. Thank God, for the warmth of familiarity.

There are some more alluring moments in Mira Nair's multi-cultural encounter between the orthodox Jewish woman Natalie Portman and Irrfan Khan, her business associate and Yvan Attal's dekko into the underpinnings of sex and the city with Ethan Hawke trying his best to seduce stranger, Maggie Q. Delicious.

Story: Former CIA spy, Bob Ho has a strange new assignment. He must play nanny to his comely neighbour's kids and ensure they go about their routine business rightly. Sure enough, this turns it to be more difficult than spying, specially since there are a bunch of Russian terrorists lurking around.

Movie Review: There's something about Jackie Chan. Something sweet and sincere that makes him eminently watchable even though he remains deadpan for most parts of his films and his action cuts follow a similar let's-defy-gravity ring to them. Nevertheless, he strikes an instant chord as the entertainer with a zing.

Here, you are willing to watch him play mommy -- and daddy -- to three kids, teaching them how to tackle the usual business of life: school, dating, bullying, bedtime and sibling strife. But he promises more than a domesticated Chan. For, when he's not singing Chinese lullabies to the little one or tutoring the 10 year-old geek on girls, he's doing his usual thing. Like, swinging across precipices, sliding down escalators, kick boxing the unknown assailant as he tries to save his newfound family from a bunch of Russian terrorists who have discovered a new bacteria that will eat up all the oil in the world. Chan must not only save the kids, he must save the world's oil too, as also his endangered romance with the kid's pretty mommy who's livid with him after she learns he's not just the nice guy next door.

Nothing original and not quite quintessential Chan -- the action here is muted -- this one's only for diehard Jackie buffs.

Story: Emily, a social worker, tries to save 10-year-old girl Lillith from her murderous parents and manages to bring her home for safe custody. But has she made the right decision? Nice people around her begin dying and too many bad things start to happen....

Movie Review: Ms Bridget Jones steps down a bit and tries her hand at a typical Hollywood horror flick. But don't be disappointed, for this one does manage to keep you in your seats, despite the no-hype, no-marketing blip surrounding it. Of course, most of the credit must go to young Ms Jodelle Ferland who pitches in a startling performance of the archetypal child-demon. As the sweet yet satanic young girl who speaks politely, smiles adoringly and poses completely vulnerable, she's almost the female avatar of Damien, the devil-boy who scared your wits out in Omen.

Zellweger saves the helpless girl from her parents while they were trying to bake her in the oven and brings her home, despite insisting she ain't mommy material. It doesn't take long for her to discover her maternal instincts, but before they can actually come into play, it's time to put the brakes. Her best friend and child psychologist, Doug (Bradley Cooper), dies a mysterious death after a frightening session with her young ward; another young boy who comes in contact with little Lillith ruthlessly hacks his parents while they slept. The idyll is short lived as the sinister begins to take a hold over the social worker's life. But is there really a way out? Can she fight the evil that has entered her house and her life? Is Case 39 actually cruel to children?

May be yes. But that's another debatable question altogether. As a film, Case 39 does work at the simple, basic level of a thriller that thrills. Although Ms Zellweger does look somewhat jaded and whispers a bit too much to create her characteristic impact.

Story: New Yorkers, Meryl and Paul Morgan are separated and on the verge of a divorce, until they witness a murder and enter the witness relocation programme. Sent off to distant and desolate Wyoming, they have a chance to rediscover each other again.

Movie Review: The last we saw Hugh Grant was as the immensely lovable crooner in Music and Lyrics. And the last we saw Sarah Jessica Parker was as the archetypal New Yorker in Sex and the City. Do we want to see this seemingly odd couple together in this romcom that really doesn't have anything new to offer? Well, okay, if you must....Totally time-pass.

The only novelty about this jaded script about a squabbling uptown couple who fall back in love is the emergence of a brand new character on Hollywood's screen. Say hello to Sarah Palin as she dons her celluloid avtar as Emma, the gun-toting wife (Mary Steenburgen) of a US marshall who has been assigned the job of protecting the Morgans as they enter a witness relocation programme to evade an assassin who's been chasing them from New York. Like Palin, Emma too is a hard-boiled carnivore who lives in the wilds, isn't intimidated by grizzlies and other wild animals and loves a mean hunt, while flashing her loaded gun and leather boots. And in case you miss the similarities, there's Mrs Morgan who exclaims 'Oh my God, that's Sarah Palin!' when she first spots her. It's here, in wild and laid back Wyoming that the Morgans get a chance to shed their big city blues and discover the joys of giving and loving...Like, sharing quiet dinners in candle light or battling bears in the backyard.

The film does have a tired Hugh Grant and a washed out Sarah Jessica Parker trying to be funny. To be fair, they do manage to make you smile, now and then, while the popcorn lasts.

Story: Micah and Katie may have moved into their new house in San Diego, but their bliss is short-lived. The couple discover a paranormal presence in their house and try to combat it with a set of video cameras and some common sense.

Movie Review: The low budget film ($15,000) has reportedly sent the world into a screaming frenzy despite its grainy look and its hand-held camera, home video kind of footage. Viewers have likened its shock and awe effects to The Blair Witch Project, with theatres in the US recording a communal frenzy of `oohs' and `aahs' in packed late night shows.

Guess we Indians are a braver lot. Didn't really feel the chill, except in one or two sequences to be honest. But more than the leap-out-of-your-seat factor, it's the sheer experimental quality of the film that needs to be savoured and saluted. Shot entirely with a hand-held camera and featuring just two people for most of the screen time, the film manages to hold your attention in an age when cinema has donned a whole new `Avtar'. Even the horror is mostly imagined, minus all special effects that generally form the core of hardcore horror films like The Exorcist. This one's more in league with Rosemary's Baby where you feel the chill without ever seeing the scare factor.

Micah tries his best to battle the unseen presence that has been following Katie ever since she was eight-years old. He buys an Ouija Board to communicate with the Thing, sprinkles powder on the floor to capture his footprints, sets up umpteen video cameras all over the house and keeps the bedroom door ajar. The couple even calls in a demonologist to give them some sane, scientific or spiritual advice. But nothing does seem to work. The bed does keep creaking at night, the stairways shake with loud thumping noises, the door shuts and opens on its own accord, the sheets get crumpled, heavy breathing fills the air and Katie begins to bruise....

Catch the night show if you actually want to feel the heebie-jeebies. And don't go looking for long-winded explanations. You might end up blaming the chill, not on winter alone.

A word about:

Performances: Both Katie Featherston and Micah Sloat are naturals. Can't tell whether they are actually acting.

Screenplay: Director Oren Peli has done the screenplay too and keeps it completely true to life. Could be happening to you and me, all this weird stuff. Phew!

Cinematography: Jerky, grainy, hand-held and completely effective. Inspires you to pick up your video-cam too for stuff that transcends the family video scene.

Story: Sherlock Holmes and his assistant, Dr John Watson think they have successfully resolved a case, when the murderer, Lord Blackwood is hanged for his crimes. But the black-magic practitioner returns from the dead to haunt London once again. Time to take up the case again.

Movie Review: Sherlock Holmes with a whole lot of hormones? Now that's not so elementary, my dear Watson! Specially, when entire generations of readers have grown up with memories of a vintage arm chair detective who never actually got his hands soiled, despite spending a lifetime tackling crime and criminals.

Story: Circa 2154. The US army lands up in Pandora, an earth-sized moon in outer space. Their objective: to extract the much-needed minerals from Pandora's soil. But before they can do that, they must fight the peace-loving indigenous inhabitants of the alien world, relocate or destroy them with their spies and bombs.

Movie Review: And we thought sinking the Titanic was a titan task! Well, this time round, James Cameron chooses to play god and creates a whole new world with such exquisite finesse, aesthete and eye for detail, he almost takes your breath away. In terms of sheer technology, Avatar marks the coming of age of both CGI and 3-D cinema with its art house special effects and its shock and awe treatment.

Story: Bella Swan's romance with high-school vampire Edward Cullen suffers a temporary break when her boy friend chooses to distance himself from the vulnerable maiden. Enter Jacob, the were-wolf hunk who protects her from the non-vegetarian vampires, thirsting for her blood.

Movie review: Some lucky girl, this Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart)! On the one hand, she manages to find the wildest boyfriends for sure: If it isn't the ashen-white and absolutely ravishing vampire, Edward Cullen (Robert Pattinson), baring his fangs for her, it's the eight-pack were-wolf, Jacob (Taylor Lautner) feverishly grinding his teeth or wolfishly blinking his eyes for her. And on the other, she manages to stay away from all the banal humans who can't even handle the adrenalin rush of an in-your-face action film. More importantly, humans hardly make ideal boyfriends in an age when it's easy to end up as Tiger(s) in the Wood(s).

Story: All's not well in Pixie Hollow. Tinker Bell has broken the fragile moonstone and failed in a task that might not bring back the Pixie Dust Tree: the source of all their magic. She must make amends with the help of her best friend Terence before the elders get to know...

Movie review: Disney still draws the line when it comes to animation, despite the surge of other production houses like Pixar and Dreamworks. The colours and the characters of Tinker Bell create a living-breathing canvas that's pure art. More importantly, the film is a must-learn lesson for Indian animators who need to take the big leap in this growing field.

This one's an archetypal fairy tale that gladdens the heart of kids and adults alike. Tinker, with her strapless green dress, her gossamer wings and her golden bun is a fiery little fairy who literally sees red when she loses her cool. And she does loose it quite often. So much so, she even manages to break the fragile and precious moonstone in a fit of fury.

She's mad at her best buddy Terence, the caretaker of the all-important pixie dust, for his meddlesome ways, even though Terence was simply trying to help her build the sceptre. This was a task assigned to her by the fairy queen and had to be completed before the Harvest Moon, if Pixie Hollow is to be saved.

With the moonstone shattered, antsy Tinker has just one option. She must fly across Neverland on a dandelion to find the magical mirror that will grant her a wish. But before she crosses the treacherous terrain, she must decide which is the real treasure: the Mirror of Incanta or her friendship with Terence.

This one's a perfect outing for the kids who will have a ball watching the pesky Trolls, taking the 21 butterfly salute or savouring the Fairy Tale Theatre orchestra made up of croaking frogs and chirping crickets.

Correction: Interestingly, we have learnt that the animation of Tinker Bell has been done in India. Kudos to the talented army of Indian animators behind this artistic work. Sadly, this fact should have been advertised upfront in the Disney marketing strategy of the film for the India release. When we say Tinker Bell should be a lesson for Indian animators, we mean all those people who are assiduously trying to promote Indian animation films as a separate, viable and vibrant genre of popular Indian cinema. Apologies if the comment has hurt our talented artists who have ventured bravely into a new world.

Story: Catherine Zeta-Jones, a 40-year-old single mom with two kids, desperately needs a nanny. She finds one in Justin Bartha, the 24-year-old coffee shop assistant who works nearby. Needless to say, romance blooms despite the age difference.

Movie review: Older woman. Smarter woman. Younger man. Desirable man. Welcome to the new age relationship which has currently become quite a craze, ever since Demi Moore proved that the much younger Ashton Kutcher could be something more than a toy boy. He could be a husband too. Hence, the allure of the older, alpha woman who's both hot and happening; a delightful blend of substance and sensuality.

That's what young and sensitive Aram Finklestein (Justin Bartha) sees in his older, wiser, absolutely oomphy employer Sandra (Catherine Zeta-Jones) when she hires him as her nanny. He does begin by baby-sitting her two kids, playing video games with them, enacting American Idol sessions or imitating the Grudge. But very soon, he graduates from just watching her mess up her dates with her sundry boyfriends to being the perfect boyfriend. The mother of two dismisses her dalliance as a one-night stand, but is forced to do a re-check when the nights keep adding up and compatibility keeps growing. This can't be for keeps, she tells herself and ticks off her boyfriend for being so young: he gets drunk on half a beer and reads Harry Potter! Time to go their separate ways? Or time to debunk all traditional limits to love and longing...

The Rebound is a sweet and sassy little romance that is watchable despite its predictability. And that's because both the lead players don't take themselves too seriously. While Justin Bartha plays nice guy without losing his sense of humour, Catherine Zeta-Jones has a lightness of being that enables her to zip through romance that might otherwise have ended up as routine. Watch her do a Jab We Met a la Kareena when she bad mouths her domineering ex-husband and tells him to rot in hell. And yes, Justin eggs her on to break her silence, just like Shahid Kapur...

A light and breezy rom-com, The Rebound keeps the popcorn buttery.

Big town corporate feminazi, Renee Zellweger, is sent to smaller town, Minnesota, to downsize a sick firm in these recessionary times. But before she can hand out the pink slips, she must contend with union leader, Harry Connick Jr. who is quite hard to ignore. And to hate...

There's something about Renee Zellweger. Something sweet and so very disarming, she makes a run-of-the-mill rom-com watchable. Ever since stealing our hearts with her girl-next-door goodness in Jerry Macguire, Renee has remained the true blue Ms Congeniality in popcorn cinema. Of course, she's a mountain of talent too, as amply displayed in Chicago, Cold Mountain and the Bridget Jones series.

Here however, it's mainly her charisma that wins you over as she brings life to Lucy, the high-heeled alpha woman who re-locates to cold and freezing Minnesota. First, there's disdain for the small town mentality and then there's love and longing for the uncluttered, closely knit, clan-nish existence of the Minnesotans that stands out in stark contrast to the I-me-mine credo of Miami. More importantly, she loses her heart to the union leader, enfant terrible Ted (Harry Connick Jr.) who predictably begins the relationship on the wrong note.

Okay, it's predictable we confess, but it's as sweet as the tapioca pudding that seems to be the main course in the film. Watch out for some syrupy moments, a mouthful on cut-throat corporate ethics and some fine performances by Renee and her personal assistant, Siobhan Fallon Hogan, who tries to set her up with the most eligible bachelor in the provincial town.

Orphan Raizo grows up into a ninja assassin after being trained by a heartless head of a warrior clan. But he turns rogue and swears revenge when the brutality of the master becomes too hard to handle.

Andy Wachowski, the younger sibling in the Wachowski Brothers Inc., confesses in an interview: ``We think movies are fairly boring and predictable. We want to scr*w with audiences' expectations.'' Larry, the elder, thinks so too. Hence the brothers Wachowski go ahead and make The Matrix series which truly turn Hollywood on its head by redefining the action genre. More importantly, they lay the foundation for their brand of cinema which is based on the quintessential American principle of shock and awe, with action as the core of their narrative.

But hey, it's not just ordinary action where guns explode and people die, any which way. Nah! Normal is truly boring for the Brothers Wachowski. Remember the gravity and speed defying action cuts of The Matrix series? Ninja Assassin, their latest production too tries to follow a similar formula where heads roll, hands are chopped, blood spurts, wounds are split wide open and hearts are gorged out...All this, without an eye-blink or a sense of extreme. The film's rated R, so no apologies for the hardcore violence. Also, it's a ninja story, isn't it. And ninja's are supposed to chop and sock their way through life. So go, get what you expect: loads of ninjas, lots of violence, neatly orchestrated martial arts' sequences and some semblance of a storyline. But no, not The Matrix.

Refreshingly, the film has a heart too. Raizo (played by South Korean pop singer, Rain), an orphan, is adopted by a cruel martial art's master who heads the Ozunu clan. The clan excels in creating killing machines out of homeless kids by divesting them of all humaneness. Extreme violence and complete heartlessness becomes a way of life for the terrified youngsters who are then supplied as mercenary killers to governments and institutions who want to assassinate anybody. Raizo does grow up to be the best amongst equals, but he goes rogue when the master kills his beloved. He teams up with a forensic researcher in Interpol (Naomie Harris) to set the record straight. And that of course means slicing up all the bad ninjas before setting up the final confrontation with the bad master.

Needless to say, it's the fight sequences that form the highlight of this film. But the film has its emotional core too as it captures the angst of young Raizo who tries to quell the thundering of his heart in a heartless world. Directed by James McTeigue (V for Vendetta) the film provides interesting viewing for hardcore action film buffs. Watch out for Karl Walter Lindenlaub's cinematography which captures the martial arts' moves in shadowy light, since the Ninja Assassins are mythical, shadowy urban legends who have been killing anyone for 100 pounds of gold over the centuries.

Story: A celluloid adaptation of Charles Dicken's classic, the story revolves around the redemption of despicable Ebenezer Scrooge who turns over a new leaf one Christmas Eve.

Movie review: It's a Jim Carrey show all the way. You may not recognise him at first due to the CGI effects, but it doesn't take long before the Carrey charisma works its magic. He brings to life a Scrooge you've never seen -- or imagined -- before, with his ill-temper and stingy ways that almost reek of cruelty. Until one cold, wintry, Christmas eve...

Scrooge scoffs at his nephew (Colin Firth) who wants to invite him for Christmas dinner and yells at his clerk (Gary Oldman), before retiring to his desolate home on Christmas Eve. But it's not going to be an ordinary Yuletide for this grumpy old man as he gets hauled up by three ghosts who hold up a mirror to his meanness. Repelled by his anti-social ways, Scrooge, the archetypal misanthrope, metamorphoses into the biggest humanitarian, overnight. He not only re-builds fences with his nephew and neighbours, but he also sends the biggest turkey in town to his impoverished clerk's family. Apart from raising his salary of course...

Loads of special effects and a story that has stood the test of time: Christmas Carol is Carrey revisited. However, it's not really a children's film and is meant for diehard Dicken's fans.

A word about...

Performances: Jim Carrey is heavily made-up, yet striking both as Scrooge and the ghosts who reform Scrooge. The rest of the actors are unrecognisable too, yet they pitch in perfectly as archetypal Dicken's characters.

Dialogue: Robert Zemeckis captures the world of Charles Dickens perfectly with his screenplay and dialogues. There's an old world charm to the way Ebenezer and the rest of the characters discover the tenets of good living.

Cinematography: Robert Presley's camera deftly oscillates between the real world, peopled by the down and out and the fantasy world, brimming over with ghosts and visions.

Bella Swann moves from her mother's home in Pheonix to live with her dad in Forks. She falls in love with Edward Cullen, the strangest and most good looking boy in class, only to discover he's a vampire.

How would you like to be a spider monkey and ride atop your boyfriend's shoulders at the speed of light on your first date which entails clambering over the tallest tree in the forest, to see the world literally lying at your feet? How would you like playing super special baseball with his family amidst thunder and lightning? How would you like a schmaltzy prom dance with him with the lights turned dim? And finally, how would you like to lie all night beside him, while he practises self-control, even while whispering how you are his personal brand of heroin: truly hard to resist?

All you Twilighters, take the first bus to your favourite audi. This one's ekdum paisa vasool fare. Stephanie Myer's mythical masala about a vegan vampire who falls in love with the girl-next-door, yet refuses to bury his fangs in her, despite the fatal attraction is hot stuff on screen. And all you non-Twilighters -- those who don't know a thing about Twilight, New Moon, Eclipse and Breaking Dawn -- don't despair. For this one's so delightfully mushy, it fills you with an adrenalin rush too. With all that hormonal rush between Edward and Bella and their valiant attempts at self-control, you feel like nodding at the moony vampire when he declares: ``I had an adrenalin rush. It happens. You can Google it.''

No need to Google, sir. We know. It happens. For, as you say, Bella smells delicious and the lion almost always does fall for the lamb. Also, as you say, being a vegetarian vampire is like being on tofu all your life: it fills your hunger, but doesn't satisfy you, unlike the blood of a beautiful maiden.

Ironically, it's all these cheesy dialogues which actually become the high point of the film which is an adaptation of Stephanie Myer's teen romance, Twilight, now acquiring cult status. Bella moves to a new town and a new high school mid-session. It's love at first sight for her when she spots Edward, the pallid hunk with painted lips and changing eye colour. The romance acquires a dangerous edge when Bella discovers her boyfriend's a vampire and her town is brimming over with other, more dangerous vampires too. It doesn't take long before she unleashes a full scale war between the vegan and non-vegan vampires. The vegans treat her as family and the non-vegans want her as snack...Truly delicious!

The film takes a bit long to build up the romance, but once it does, there's no looking back. Kristen Stewart's Bella however isn't as alluring as Robert Pattinson's Edward, now a cult figure in popular culture. Pattison does the tightrope between the undead (he's been 17 since 1918) and the living (he can practice self-control) amicably. But the film actually works because it sculpts a romance that blooms through self-denial and renunciation. Grab your munchies and go for it!
A word about...

Performances: It's a Robert Pattinson show all the way. His vampire act is quite irresistible, even though he doesn't have much to do in the acting department. Edward Cullen works more because of his body language: tall, muscular, ashen-white, cold yet so very passionate. Kristen Stewart's Bella Swann is relatively too simple and flaccid to hold your attention.

Dialogues: Melissa Rosenberg renders a faithful adaptation of Stephanie Myer's teen fantasy. The conversation between the vampire and his love are syrupy and sweet: truly the stuff teen romances are made of. Sample this: It's your smell! You're like a drug for me. It's like my own personal brand of heroin, mutters a desperate Edward.

Cinematography: Elliot Davis creates enough spookiness with the camera to match the supernatural antics of the vampires. The small town of Forks is wet, sunless, misty and a perfect setting for an unnatural love story.

Story: The sun's sending extra heat due to which planet Earth has a destabilising crust. End result? It's hurtling towards doomsday in 2012, as predicted by the Mayan calendar. Can a father, John Cusack, save his family, a President, Danny Glover, his country, a scientist, Chiwetel Ejiofor, the future...?

Movie Review: End of the world movies have almost always been engaging. Also, director Roland Emmerich has ended the world time and again through his celluloid epics. Be it the aliens bringing the White House down, the world going into deep freeze or the giant lizard trampling across terra firma, films like Independence Day, The Day After Tomorrow and Godzilla have showcased Emmerich as an able prophet of doom. Once again, he churns the oceans, cracks up the earth and sends down fireballs to create a cataclysm that sends humanity into a tizzy. Everyone's on the run, now that they know Earth has an expiry date: December 2012. And before the new world can begin (circa 0001), with a handful of survivors, families must unite, loved one's must be lost, the benevolent must shine and the bad guys be sorted out...In short, the entire gamut of emotions must be run through, even if it takes a prolonged two and half hours to depict the might of man against the fury of nature. Yes, 2012 is too long and ends up taxing your patience in the last 40 minutes where all the drama unfolds inside a submarine-like Noah's ark, brimming over with the survivors, handpicked on different yardsticks. Most of them are there because they could afford to buy themselves a one billion euro berth in the secret ship. Some have connections (like the US president's daughter, the White House chief), some because the new world needs them, like the bright, young scientist, Chiwetel Ejifor, and some -- the good, yet ordinary guys -- are gatecrashers and stowaways (John Cusack and his estranged family). But human drama isn't supposed to be the highlight of any disaster film. Special effects are the main draw. So, you actually don't mind the perfunctory manner in which the director handles his characters' bondings. There's Cusack trying to re-bond with his separated wife (Amanda Peet) and kids. There's the scientist torn with grief because he can't take his dad on the secret ship. There's the US Prez (Danny Glover) who chooses not to abandon his countrymen and prefers to look for a kid's lost daddy, when doom dawns. And there's the scheming wannabe (Oliver Platt) who dreams of becoming Prez when the new world order begins. Oh yes, amongst all these usual types, there's also the mad prophet of doom cum radio jockey (Woody Harrelson), who wants to be the first to bring the news, even if it means standing in the face of a volcano. All the characters try to hold your attention as they battle apocalyptical blues.

But what really holds your attention is apocalypse itself. Yes, it's the special effects of the film, more than the human drama, which completely sweep you off your feet. You get a cheesy thrill watching larger-than-life waves, fissures, tsunamis and volcanic eruptions wipe off all the famous monuments of the world. The White House is washed away. Eiffel Tower is knocked down. The Sistine Chapel cracks up. Los Angeles splits and California falls off into the sea. And all that survives is a little plane that flys through the falling landscape and a specially crafted ship: a symbol of the invincible human spirit. Truly, there's no one better than Hollywood, when it comes to shock and awe cinema. Director Emmerich knows he can only score with this just-another-disaster flick if he creates a bigger bang when the world ends. And it's here that he succeeds. Despite being low on the emotional quotient, with characters that can be easily forgotten, 2012 remains a larger-than-life entertainer due to its visual splendour.

And for the desi viewers, there is the special tribute the filmmaker pays to India. It's an Indian astrophycist, Satnam,(Jimy Mistry), working somewhere in East India, who cautions the world about the impending doom. So what if he's the archetypal third world citizen, forced to speak English with a desi accent. And so what if he is conveniently forgotten when the exodus begins. At least the American scientist in the survivors' ship, remembers him when the end begins and the desi geek is washed away by a tsunami, family et al. Shabash India!

A word about:

Performances: No one's great. Everyone's okay, just fitting into their roles, without taking your breath away. John Cusack perfects his hangdog look as the ordinary man wih the spirit of a hero, while Amanda Peet doesn't really have much to do. Thandie Newton, a fine actress otherwise, is completely wasted too as the First Daughter. The only actor who stands out amidst the crowd is Chiwetel Ejiofor as the American scientist. And only just.

Story: Scripted by producer-director Roland Emmerich and Harald Kloser, the film kowtows the demands of a disaster film: it has a flimsy storyline, focussing primarily on survival and unfolds mostly through special effects.

Cinematography: Great camera work by Dean Semler. The end of the world sequences are absolutely magnificent as are the daring little vignettes of human valour.

Special Effects: Mike Vezina is the special effects supervisor. And Mike Vezina deserves a kudos. For watching California falling off the map of the world or LA cracking up into a grand canyon sets you gawking like never before.

Corporate crimes have acquired a whole new importance and become Hollywood's favourite subject every since Enron, the Lehman Brothers et al.

But The Informant! is such a compelling picture of a corporate criminal, it catapults you to the edge of your seat after a langorous beginning that tends to lull you into a sense of false security.

But hey, just don't sit back and think that this one's just another flick about corrupt trade practices and evil CEOs who see nothing wrong in fixing prices and taking their consmers for a ride. Because more than the unethical policies of Archer Daniel's Midlands, one of the ten largest corporations in America. Soderberh's expose is actually on Mark Whitacre (Matt Damon), the seemingly commonplace official-turned-whistleblower who would have slipped into anonymity if he didn't display his chameleon colours en route the perilous journey.

Whitacre begins low key, joining hands with the FBI as their special agent who is hellbent on exposing the unfair trade practices of his company. He calls himself 0014 because he's twice as smart as James Bond. Now that's a fact we learn very soon, as whitacre sheds all his holier-than-thou credentials and turns up a criminal himself. Not only has he been playing whistleblower for devious ends -- he hopes to become CEO of his company by getting the top brass out -- he has also been amassing ill-gotten wealth to the tune of $7 million. Or is it $11 million. And the high point is the fact that neither he nor his adoring wife (Melanie Lynskey) think he is a law breaker.

The film is based on a book by Kurt Eichenwald and features a real life case. ADM was actually sued and fined $100 million for corporate fraud while Mark Whitacre served a long prison sentence, even though he became an American hero who currently heads a hi-tech firm in the US. The film draws its allure from the scintillating performance by Matt Damon who displays a rare psychological depth while bringing to life a character who is so normal, you just can't tell...what's more, he doesn't believe there are any aberrations in his personality, even though he is a habitual liar and a natural-born felon. Watch him fib his way before the FBI: he takes your breath away.

This one's a compelling drama that's definitely not to be missed.

Anyone for a syrupy, mushy, unadulterated romance about a devoted-till-death wife (Rachel McAdams) and a disappearing husband (Eric Bana)?

This one's definitely for the diehard romantics who like their stories Mills & Boon style. More importantly, it has that delicious touch of the supernatural which makes the mating and meeting unpredictable and non-linear.

Eric Bana calls himself a time traveler because he has a genetic disorder that causes him to flit between different time zones. All his travellings happens involuntarily and sees him suddenly disappearing and reappearing, much to the discomfiture of all, but one. And that's his wife, Rachel McAdams, who meets him as a young girl offering him a blanket as he apparates as an adult, in the buff, before her. The duo stay together and build up a warm and vibrant relationship despite the time-span variance. The problem in this paradise is Bana's ability to peep into the future, but McAdam is willing to conquer all, in the name of love. Even a time-traveling pregnancy!

Based on the novel by Audrey Niffenegger, the film is a lyrical and laid back odyssey of love.

From the vampire-ridden Underworld to sub-zero Antarctica: Kate Bekinsale sure has exotic playgrounds to strut her stuff. But unlike her gothic charms in the Underworld series, Whiteout sees her pallid and frost bitten (she even loses her fingers to frost bite), moving around in heavy thermals and parka hoods for most of the film. Of course, she gets one shower scene to infuse some heat.

But that's not enough. The drama mostly remains tepid in this thanda thriller that follows the pattern of a routine whodunit as Bekinsale, a US law enforcement officer, tries to chase a hooded, pickax-wielding killer determined to create havoc in the uneventful McMurdo Station in Antarctica. Bekinsale, herself, is quite unsettled, with a stormy past and an uncertain present. She wants to quit and is all set to board the last plane out of Antarctica which leaves in half an hour. But duty calls and the diehard Marshal must ferret out the face of terror from the bunch of men who surround her.

The film fails to exploit the exotic locales of the South Pole and the twists and turns are mostly predictable in this tundra thriller which is based on a graphic novel by Greg Rucka.

MJ mania may not reach its hysterical peak with this documentary. But that's not the purpose anyways, for the pop artist has already created a fan following and a fervour that will outlive almost anything...maybe global warming, terrorism and the nuclear holocaust too.

MJ mania may not reach its hysterical peak with this documentary. But that's not the purpose anyway, for the pop artist has already created a fan following and a fervour that will outlive almost anything...maybe global warming, terrorism and the nuclear holocaust too. Instead, the film works like osmosis. It filters the hysteria into pure devotion. If you had moonwalked and clutched your crotch to Michael Jackson's songs till now, you'll silently send him a salaam, heavenwards, saluting the genius -- and the genteelness -- of a man who gave a whole new meaning to the word ‘entertainer’. The film does stay away from the very personal side of the enigmatic artist, leaving you lusting for a closer dekko at the tormented insides of a man who made a million headlines with his unconventional life and his rule-breaking ways. But when it comes to his music, 'This Is truly It'. Ortega's documentary works magic like a life-altering extended MJ extravaganza, bringing you all his best numbers -- 'Billie Jean', Beat It, Thriller, Man in the Mirror, Feel the Love and more -- leaving you breathless in the end. And completely awestruck too, with the sheer genius of a singer who lived and breathed music for 44 years (out of 50), selling an estimated 750 million albums worldwide.

So, on the one hand, you have Michael, the performer, upfront, with his somewhat squeaky voice that explodes in a pronounced vibrato as his crotch-grab, in lurex jackets and pants, creates a mesmeric vision. On the other, you have Michael, the man, who not only knows his music to perfection, but treats his team like a perfect gentleman too. Bless you, love you punctuate his pep talk, as his team lovingly labours to project and package him as a living legend. And when he's not getting the right note from his fellow artists, he tells them `it's your time to shine...let go...' Yes, Michael was the visionary who knew every tenor of the music he wanted to create and did not rest until he struck the perfect note. Let's take them to worlds they've never been before, let's show them talent they've never seen before, he gently exhorted.

Indeed, take your chance. Go where you've never been before. Witness the concert that might have been. Experience the magic of a man who made you jump over the moon.

The film, set in two time zones, traces the story of two inveterate foodies: Julia Child (Meryl Streep) and Julie Powells (Amy Adams) who mastered the zen of cooking and the art of life, simultaneously.

If Julia began her culinary journey in the 1940s and taught America how to cook with her skills at French cuisine, then Julie discovered the joy of living in an otherwise joyless life by blogging about 524 recipes in 365 days. Needless to say, Julie, a call centre worker, wasting away during the day in a dull cubicle, drew her inspiration from Julia, the perfect wife and the enviable cook.

Director Nora Ephron essentially paints portraits of feminine power through her two disparate characters who may be leading dissimilar lives, yet, they are actually two sides of the same coin. Their lives seem to move parallel in an interesting intercutting that traces their journey from boredom to fame as they learn to whip up the cream in their lives. Julia is a bored housewife who lives in Paris with her devoted diplomat husband (Stanley Tucci). Juile is a phone-in assistant who spends her time answering calls on insurance queries from 9/11 victims. She too lives with a much-in-love husband (Chris Messina) who can afford barely a tiny room above a pizzeria in Queens which doubles up as the couple's love nest. Julia takes up cooking as an escape from unexciting bridge classes while Julie takes it up to bide over her daily tedium, as also a tribute to her icon, Julia, the author of the cult book, Mastering the Art of French Cooking, meant exclusively for the `servantless' American homes.

The film draws most of its charm from the performances and the character studies. Based on real life characters, Ephron relies heavily on Streep to recreate the magic she displayed in The Devil Wears Prada and Adaptation. Streep doesn't disappoint although her Julia is such an exaggerated character, it could have almost ended up a caricature. Amy Adams too is warm and vibrant as the spitfire Julie who gets so immersed in mastering the art of boning the duck or stirring beef stew, she almost breaks up her marriage.

Did you know that guinea pigs are almost human. Well, actually 98 per cent human, as their DNA declares. So what are they doing in pet shops and burrows, playing around as paltry rodents when they can actually be saving the world as special agents working with the FBI.

Phew! Did we overdo it? Not really. Because Yeatman's film actually makes the heroics of this furry bunch of don't-call-us-rodents seem plausible. The leader of the pack is Darwin (Sam Rockwell), ably assisted by Blaster (Tracy Morgan), Juarez (Penelope Cruz) and Speckles (Nicholas Cage) who happens to be a mole, abeit, the smartest one around, specially with computers. Our personal favourite? Juarez, the feisty femme fatale, who knows how hard it is to survive in a man's world, specially when the man in her life (Darwin) doesn't seem to be interested in her. When she is forced to go underground and live as a little girl's pet, our spunky amazon threatens to eat up her owner's tiny hands when she paints her nails, perches a tiara on her furry head and colours her lips pink. I feel like Paris Hilton's chihuahaha, she yells and tears off everything, except the trendy earring. The foursome, working with their owner Zack Galifianakis (Remember The Hangover?), must sabotage the plans of evil electronic billionaire (Bill Nighy) who wants to launch a world threatening project, Clusterstorm, with his military chip equipped electronic goods.

The action is fun, the humour crisp, the voice-overs effective. Just one sore point: Zack is completely wasted as the guinea pigs' sidekick, specially after a scintillating show in The Hangover.

This one's for all those young adults out there. No preaching. No bhashans. Plain and simple buddy talk... on world peace, on global warming, on the flip side of technology, on true friendships, on sibling relationships, on teen-parent bonding

So far so good. And then begins the magic. A colourful magical rock that helps our young hero ``make a wish'' which includes giving it back to the school bully, creating a special fort full of crocodiles and snakes, special superpowers to fly to school, unlimited supply of chocolates, fighting the bad guy. Sadly, the magic soon goes from pillar to post creating utter confusion and chaos in Black Hills. But hold on: our hero finally thinks it best to use it for global warming and world peace. Of course, he later throws it away. Surprised? We don't really need a magic stone to tackle global warming, terrorism, world peace and even relationships with parents (``The cellphones disconnects us from real interaction. So dump it'' is just one real suggestion).

Wondering what's short about Shorts? Not the message. Not even the chaos. Just the lack of hi-tech special effects and the chaotic structure of the story which lurches back through a series of disjointed flashbacks (called shorts). And that's where you might end up blinking!

Fun, nevertheless.

Everybody knows about Woodstock, the milestone music concert that changed the world. But does anybody know about the people who made it possible, besides the musicians and the hippies who are now part of history?

Here's where Ang Lee's film scores, turning its attention away from the actual concert and the larger-than-life artists to the freedom-loving commoners who saw the cause behind the concert.

Based on Elliot Tiber's book, the film focuses more on the experiences of a conventional youngster who lives a predictable, unexciting life with his parents, rather than the rule-breakers and the flower people. Young Elliot isn't wrong when he exclaims he is that rare breed of youth who chooses to have breakfast, every morning, with his parents (Henry Goodman and Imelda Staunton), while helping them to run their decrepit motel, the El Monaco. The only unconventional element in his life is the bunch of hippies living in his barn, much to the discomfiture of his stern, disciplinarian mom.

But Elliot gets his chance to discover his wild side when he lets out his land to the music producer (Jonathan Groff) who wants to organise the Woodstock music concert, simply because `there's a lot of joy of music' and he wants to share the joy with the world. Elliot's journey to adulthood begins as he hobnobs with the hippies and discovers the libertine way of life.

For those expecting a blast of flower power hysteria, the film might be a disappointment. As it would for those expecting another Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon from a high-on-style Ang Lee. But for those who'd like to decipher why the hippie cult was so alluring to the earth-bound, Taking Woodstock is low-key yet lyrical.

Ready for a robotic Bruce Willis? Not really, specially when the diehard cop has already won our hearts with his superhero-in-singlet status.

So, we do feel somewhat discomforted when a flesh and blood Bruce is forced to play battered, bruised, and bleeding too, while being bound to a couch, even as his plastic and metal body double is sent out to save the world. Reason? The real Bruce is too sad after having lost his son and almost losing his wife (Radha Mitchell) to unbearable grief.

Things do brighten up when Bruce's surrogate suffers a mishap and the cop is forced to come out of semi-retirement to solve the murder of several surrogates, in a futuristic world that is fast learning to say no to robots and reserving special places `only for humans'. It's a move that sees Bruce not only cleaning up the metallic grime, but also infusing a whole lot of Emotional Quotient back into a mecha world. And yes, it's a step that gets him back to his not-so-perfect wife who had sent out her coiffured surrogate to cope with harsh reality.

Watch out for the action sequences and Bruce Willis trying to replay some of Arnold Schwarzenneger's Terminator magic.

The captured Nazi officer is defiant, almost pugnacious. *uck you, he says, to officer Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) ferreting him for information.

The answer to that is a moment of silence. Soon we hear the first notes of eerie music, a foreboding of something sinister. Then from the heart of a tunnel a shadowy figure emerges with a baseball bat in hand. What we witness in the next few seconds is violence in its most raw and pristine form. The baseball bat comes with the swiftness of a hurricane and the savage power that only pure hate can unleash. We hear the sound of wood meeting skull. It's gruesome. It's Quentin Tarantino - with the subtext that the Allies were pretty brutal too.

Inglourious Basterds isn't littered with such moments of intense savagery though one also gets to see scalps being knifed off the skull. But watching it we always feel a sense of looming menace that's almost Hitchcockian. In ordinary situations - be it a German officer drinking milk or biting into his apple strudel with fresh cream - we sense the possibilities of limitless terror, touch the mad angles of fear.

Tarantino tells the story in chapters. The movie has the feel of reading a novel visually. Not every chapter is immediately linked to what has happened before. But that's Tarantino. We know the jigsaw pieces will eventually fall into place.

Inglourious Basterds is certainly not the sort of wartime yarn that Hollywood produced with relish in the 1960s: The Great Escape, The Dirty Dozen and many more. By the time the lights come on, we know we haven't been watching pure history either. Instead, we catch engrossing drama created by long dialogues. The scenes are unhurried. We get a 1940s sense of time. The opening scene, primarily a conversation between a French farmer and an SS Colonel, lasts almost 20 minutes.

Most Tarantino flicks generally have a stand-out performer. Here it is Christoph Waltz, the Jew-hunting German colonel. Charming, intelligent and ruthless --- Waltz gets every aspect of the part spot-on. Without him, Inglourious Basterds wouldn't have been half the movie it is. As a nonchalant, almost careless leader of the inglourious basterds team, Brad Pitt throws in a heavy accent but is pretty lightweight otherwise.

Inglourious Basterds isn't heavy adrenalin action. It's a war movie without much war but plenty of menace. It's a sort of exploration of mentalities that wars create in us: reasons to kill, an urge to hurt. The movie needs to be enjoyed slowly like good wine. There's pleasure in its details. But you'll have to do the hard work of finding them yourself, as in any decent work of art.

Every other child in the orphanage is playing. She is the only one who sits alone painting. That's when John Coleman (Peter Sarsgaard) walks into the room.

He is impressed by her work and strikes up a conversation. Esther, the nine-year-old orphan (Isabelle Fuhrman), turns out to be mature, bright and well-mannered. Almost immediately, John and his wife Kate (Vera Farmiga) adopt her.

Kate has a history of tragedy; she has lost her third baby in childbirth. Trouble keeps chasing her like bumblebees. She has just overcome a drinking problem and her visits to the psychiatrist continue. But she is smarter than her husband and can see what he doesn't: that Esther is far too self-assured and measured to be a child. When things start going wrong -- she is always found in places where murder, beatings, arson happen – in the beautiful wood-panelled house they live in, she knows something is very wrong.

Orphan makes sinister sexy. Logic isn't always the script's strong point. But director Jaume Collet-Serra forces you to gloss over them. The film is shot in winter, the sheet of cold white across the canvas helps build the movie's dark mood.

The script is favourably disposed to Esther. And Fuhrman shines in the part of a Russian orphan who plays Tchaikovsky like a master and wields the pickaxe like a demon. Somewhere in the middle of the movie we come to know that she is capable of expressing her darkest emotions through violence. But to what degree can she succeed? That's what keeps us hanging to the edge of our seats.

Orphan is chilling without trying too hard to be so. And as we move towards the climax, it almost turns horrifying. Those who enjoy getting up, close and personal with evil will love this. But those who want to adopt a child might well end up having second thoughts.

With director Sam Mendes, you can always expect the unexpected. He has done the dark comedy (American Beauty), the gangsta flick (Road to Perdition), the brutally introspective (Jarhead) and the off-beat drama (Revolutionary Road).

In an age when most prefer to play safe, he is happy experimenting with genres. And that's worthy of admiration. In Away We Go as well, Mendes walks a different path, crafting a movie that smells like a road flick but is actually a drama without drama.

Middle-aged and middle-class, Burt (John Krasinski) and Verona (Maya Rudolph) aren't married but certainly a couple. The first scene shows a head bobbing up and down beneath the sheets with Burt making loud noises as if eating a hot pickle. We soon get to see the after-effects of that amorous night – Verona's six-month swollen tummy that looks it has an eight-month baby inside.

The journey towards parenthood evokes a host of emotions in the couple: none stronger than anxiety. And when Burt's parents surprise them by announcing that they are moving to Antwerp for a couple of years, they know that changing diapers at 2 am isn't going to be their only problem. As the two embark on a journey that takes them to places like Phoenix, Tucson, Madison, Montreal and Miami (in that order), they seem to discover more about life and togetherness. In the end, there's no great illumination. But perhaps more understanding, more wisdom that might help them sail the choppy seas of parenthood together.

Away We Go has some masterly old soundtracks from George Harrison, Bob Dylan and Lou Reed. Languidly paced, it has symmetry all its own. But in the end, it is like a could-have-been-good flick that leaves you less than satisfied and vaguely unfulfilled. We really don't know what the two protagonists are looking for. Their friends and relatives – Verona's friend who can't speak a sentence without using the F-word, the breast-feeding pal who hates rollers and a relative who philosophises as he pours syrup over toast, 'You have to be willing to make the family from whatever' – don't seem characters from everyday life but plucked from the margins. Perhaps, Mendes is trying to tell us, each to his own. That's a good philosophy to live with. But you need not watch a weekend movie to know that.

Every once in a while comes a movie as endearing as a grandmother's lap, as joyous as Tendulkar on song. UP is that kind of a movie: a magical joyride on 10,000 balloons that fills you with an unbearable lightness of being, and literally as well as figuratively, takes you to cloud nine.

Crafted in the Disney-Pixar stable, Oscar-nominated director Pete Docter's flight of imagination evokes the feel of adventure, comedy and drama -- sometimes all at the same time. And if you occasionally get the impression of watching a buccaneering cartoon version of Indiana Jones, that's ok too.

The movie's first 15 minutes are its weakest. And on first impression, there is little appealing about UP's protagonist: Carl Fredricksen, a grumpy, pugnacious widower with a shock of white hair, big glasses and the squarest face you will ever see. Perhaps the oldest Hollywood hero of this millennium, Carl is still wedded to the memory of his wife (Ellie) who has left behind an album of their unfulfilled dream: a visit to Paradise Falls in South America. Part of the old man's crankiness comes from a feeling of helplessness. The land surrounding his house has been taken over by real estate builders. The noise and dust raised by the construction irritates Carl. That's why he turns snappy when egg-headed Russell, an earnest but bumbling kid, knocks at his door.

But Carl has a surprise for everyone. Using helium-filled balloons, he hauls his house above the ground and makes it soar. With Russell as accidental company, a rollicking voyage follows --- in the air and on the ground --- as a crazy explorer and his ferocious pack of dogs hunt for a rare multi-coloured bird that the duo has discovered. Two of an unkind, Carl and Russell make a great team. The change of tenor in their relationship -- from tolerance to bonding --- never feels fake.

It's been six years since Finding Nemo (2003) hit the screens but we still fondly and vividly remember the small fish, his father, even those sharks with mouths wider than India Gate. The characters of UP are equally unforgettable. Kevin, the flightless bird that looks like an ostrich but is feathered like a rainbow, is delightful. The scene where she flings Russell like a ball of wool in the air and rocks him like a baby makes for the movie's most affectionate moments. And Dug, the golden mutt who behaves like a lamb, is as cute as it gets.

Neatly scripted with first-rate production values --- in the climax, the swordfights and the fighter aircraft stunts are edge-of-the-seat stuff --- UP is like a wish granted for all. What more can you ask for in times of swine flu and fake austerity measures?

At a time when Hollywood can't have enough of romantic comedies, extreme action and sci-fi adventure comes a family drama that's both powerful and rewarding.

Part of My Sister's Keeper is about the ethics that often involve issues of life and death. But for much of it, it is simply a compelling story of the Fitzgerald family, of the things that hold them together and the issues that make them fall apart. The movie sucks you into their lives.

The story is centred around two sisters -- Kate (Sofia Vassilieva) and Anna (Abigail Breslin). Their lives are not entirely their own. Kate has leukaemia and Anna was procreated by parents (Cameron Diaz and Jason Patric) to keep her elder sister alive. Kate loves her sister madly. But when it comes to donating her kidney, she refuses and goes to a lawyer for medical emancipation.

It is a far more complicated affair but the beauty of My Sister's Keeper lies in the way director Nick Cassavetes (The Notebook) handles his material fashioned from Jodi Picoult's novel. Wonderfully edited, the movie moves back and forth in time but never loses narrative focus. It helps that the movie has some wonderful soundtrack that articulate the mood of its strategic moments.

The key characters stand out: Sarah (Cameron Diaz), the strong and opinionted mother who's too blinded by the idea of prolonging her daughter's life to see the big picture, Brian (Jason Patric), the fireman father who has the wisdom and the heart to see what's going wrong. So do Kate and Anna - who follow the voices of their hearts in their own way. Even the minor characters -- the attorney and the judge -- are wonderfully etched.

Two scenes will long stay in memory. One, where love happens in the time of chemotherapy as Kate falls for a young patient undergoing treatment. The desire to bond and seek every form of pleasure at the time of dying is both touching and tear-drawing. Two, when the family takes Kate, by then in an advanced stage of the disease, to the beach. Those movie minutes are touched by magic.

The beauty of My Sister's Keeper is that despite all the talk of death, it never feels morbid, even heavy. 'There's no shame in dying,' says the judge, at one point. And we agree with her.

Grim and nerve-jangling, this one's for every hardcore sci-fi fan. When a spaceship lands in Johannesburg (probably because director Neill Blomkamp is a South African), humans need to evict the aliens because living space is scarce.

So eager hero Wikus Van De Merwe (Sharlto Copley), who works at Multi-National United (MNU), is sent with troops to politely ask the aliens to leave. Incidentally, MNU also happens to be the second largest weapon manufacturer in the world and is interested in alien weapons. To further spice up the scene, Nigerian gangs abound in District 9 and regularly resort to voodoo and killing of the aliens to imbibe `powers from outer space'.

District 9 is about the tussle between humans and aliens, the former hanker after power and weaponry while the latter (a la ET) only want to go home.

Full marks to first-time director Blomkamp for making the audience actually feel the helplessness and despair of the ugly mechanised creatures. Copley makes it almost impossible to believe this is his first film as an actor. He's also the film's co-producer with Peter Jackson. Disturbingly powerful visual effects and a dark background score add to the film's appeal. Worth a viewing but make sure you only catch the English version. There's also a Hindi version doing the rounds.

In times when men often have smoother cheeks than the women they date, the rules of romance have changed. Sensitive is in, rough is out. But Mike Chadway (Gerald Butler) has a time-tested theory of what men want.

Beneath the veneer of soft and soulful, he believes, all men have only one thing on their minds. Or, is it two? 'We all fall in love with t*ts and ar*e,' he declares early. For him, that's the ugly truth that women chasing dreamboats constructed from paperback romantic novels must wake up to.

The post-Apocalyptic world is a bleak, dark place filled with industrial wreckage. Against this backdrop, director Shane Acker crafts a multi-layered tale that can be enjoyed as much by pre-teens as their papas.

Film: 9 (animation, adventure)
Cast: Voices of Elijah Wood, Jennifer Connelly, Christopher Plummer, John C Reilly, Crispin Glover
Director: Shane Acker
Duration: About one hour and 15 minutes
Critic Rating:
*

9 is unrelenting in its visual grimness: the silent factories with giant wheels, the huge eerie black towers, the metal garbage strewn across the landscape - all combine to create a savage setting. But it is the state-of-the-art special effects and great lens-work that create a really engrossing flick. The action sequences, especially the one involving a maniacal, metallic flying beast, are wonderfully crafted.

What elevates 9 a notch above the regular sci-fi tale is its ability to create empathy for its strange-looking heroes: the stitchpunks. The cute midget-sized figures with big, round expressive eyes take the fight to the giant machines. It is the typical David and Goliath setting. But we root for the 'small creations' for their willingness to challenge themselves against impossible odds. They become what we perhaps aspire to be.

The lead characters have numbers as names. The movie borrows its title from the name of the gang's young leader. 9 is aggressive and intelligent whereas 1, the wise Oriental-looking patriarchal leader, is cautious. 1 wants to hide, 9 wants to fight. Their debate becomes a lesson in decision-making. In the end, the scientist regrets making the machines that destroyed mankind (and womankind too) because he realizes that they can be corrupted by the corrupt. In its sub-text, 9 urges us to avoid the pitfall.

At one level, 9 can be enjoyed purely as a racy sci-fi fantasy weaved around the time-honoured themes of bravery and friendship. But the movie, co-produced by Tim Burton, can also be viewed as a moral document, as an allegory of choices. Either way, 9 is fine.

There's an old joke about a 3D movie. A man watching a 3D flick asks the guy sitting in front of him, 'Please take off your hat. It is blocking my view.

'Damn it,' the man replies, 'I am in the movie.' Now with high-definition 3D technology, that joke is almost true.

Watching the speed machines in top gear in The Final Destination, you feel you're sitting in the middle of the racetrack in danger of being run over. And on more than one occasion, you shift uneasily to avoid getting hit by flying objects, mostly body parts of the actors. One shot where a flying tyre hits a young woman spilling her guts out would delight blood and gore addicts.

But the 3D novelty wears off in about 15 minutes. Then the movie has little to offer except more of the same. Every scene is scripted to show new ways of dying - getting dragged in a tow truck that explodes or getting sucked in a swimming pool exhaust and the likes. By the end, even biology students and cannibals would have had difficulty in naming the different parts of human anatomy on view: intestines, heart, marrow.

State-of-art technology must upgrade a good narrative but cannot act as its substitute. Sadly, The Final Destination tries precisely that.

Yes, the con is on. This time with globe trotting that just got a little more exciting with con men, do-or-die situations, catchy one liners, run of the mill ideas, convoluted crime, the scenic beauty of Prague, moves where nothing's spelled out and brothers Stephen and Bloom.
The mission, of course, is for ``everyone to get what everyone wants''. But before that there's the growing-up years of the executor of the plan Bloom, (Adrien Brody) and the man calling the shots, Stephen (Mark Ruffalo) who run from one foster home to the other with their little tricks, petty lies, numerous runs, little cons, big cons, complex cons and the last and final con.

Enter show stopper heiress Penelope (Rachel Weisz). Typical of most rich Hollywood heiresses, what makes her stand out is what she loves doing: Chainsaw juggling, learning rap music, excelling in the Japanese art of Origami. In short what she calls collecting hobbies. But it's only when brother Bloom falls in love with the charming Penelope that the trick and treat story gets even more deadly. That Penelope may end up being more unpredictable than all the crookster combined is another tale all together. A special mention for Rinko Kikuchi who despite the limited vocabulary of three English words steals the show as the brothers silent assistant, Bang Bang, in a world that know no cellphones and mad hurry, but cravats, black hats, retro style statements.

But does everyone get what everyone wants? Indeed! While little Bloom gets to be the author of his own ``unwritten life'' as a hopeless romantic type rather than big bro, senior Bloom finds solace in his self-created anti-hero character. Penelope, of course finds purpose and love in life. Is it that simple? Nah! For all through the process, no one ever really knows who is pulling a fast one.

As for you, there's loads of twists and turns on this road full of bumpy rides. Of course, with ample fun en route! So just in case you feel being taken for a ride is in right now, go for it. You won't regret it!

Remember your boyhood when life revolved around your Hasbro heroes. Now, move over to the future with next generation spy gadgets, military gizmos used by Team G.I. Joe right from the scorching Egyptian desert to the freezing polar ice caps.

What you have is an action-filled adventure with classic confrontations, high-tech weaponry and enough Joe versus the evil battle scenes to satisfy action fans of all age group. Yes, the idea as in all G.I. movies is a war of the good against the evil. In this case, to fight the corrupt arms dealer Destro (Christopher Eccleston) and the growing menace of the Cobra organization that threatens the world with chaos unlimited. In other words, there's enough in the movie to be termed as yet another guy thing. Not just for the dhoom dhamaka, but also for its characters.

In this case, Baroness (Seinna Miller), incidentally the movie's most compelling character, with her new brunette look, black leather outfit, sexy glasses, one-of-its-kind dialogue delivery and her I-am-the-pure-evil attitude that has enough oomph to keep the adrenalin pumping. Of course, super villainy is reserved for the Cobra Commander (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) often disguised in varied garbs. As for the rest, there's the battle scenes between rival characters, Snake Eyes (Ray Park) and Storm Shadow (Byung-hun Lee), as the real heroes Duke (Channing Tatum ) and Ripchord (Marlon Wayans) convincingly portray a combo of a Bond-ish brawn and some superhero teamwork.

So if non-stop action thrills is what you're looking for and we don't really mind a rather not-so-packed storyline, it's time to join the G.I. Joe heroes. Of course, with loads of violence, guns, wildly racing cars, laser beams, bomb blasts, explosions, special effects, battles scenes... Enough to keep you on the edge of your seat.

Jenny gave him his first friendship ever. Jenny gave him his first moment of jealousy. Jenny gave his first gift ever. Jenny gave him his first camera.

And thus was born superstar photographer Connor Mead, who gave Jenny her first heart burn ever. And like all previous rich, spoilt brats, Connor too thinks marriage is an archaic, corrupt institution that needs to be abolished ASAP, and casual sex is but no crime at all. Now, haven't we seen all that before!
Hold on. This time there's a change of our no-heart-just-mind hero who is man enough to admit he was stupid: it's the heart that rules the world more than the head. Courtesy, (no not Jenny), but three ghosts in one single pre-wedding night, led by none other than his iconic uncle, Wayne. So what if the icon admits living life his style ain't a sign of the sane. And the rest as we know, is history. Enter the great transformation of the herbivore man to soppy romantic.

But what really seems to work here are the extremely watchable characters. First is Connor Mead ( McConaughey) perfect as the over-tanned ladies' man, minus those fruity lovey-dovey speeches, who thinks the real problem is that he loves all women. Adding the much-needed (and perhaps the must-watch) comic grace is Uncle Wayne (Michael Douglas) who's hilariously well-cast as the lecherous uncle and mentor. For the record, he's never worn a seat belt and can't teach our wannabe playboy algebra or ethics, but only ``matters pertaining to dames''. But the real heart of the film is Jenny (Jennifer Garner), who manages to convey a realistic combo of brittleness, female strength, loads of rage and longing, even as she thinks Mr playboy is actually a sweetheart. So what if the star shutterbug is not good at taking pics of those with clothes on! At least he could woo her!

So, just in case you like a romcom that tugs at your heart strings, there's loads of senti speeches, overwhelming cuteness, romantic-realisation-of-love moments, tender touches till our hero realises he's got all except the love of his life. Of course, with its share of a few funny sequences in that night of realisation -- a downpour of chocolates (gifted by our playboy to the ones he cheated), tissues (used by our playboys' ex girlfriends after he dumped them) and certain unmentionable ofcourse.
