Santosh Sivan's cinema scores mostly through its picturesque frames, with the camera, rather than the characters, doing most of the story-telling.

Here too, he captures the backwaters of Kerala with exquisite artistry and creates a period film that lives more through its visual opulence than its story.

Henry Moore has a dream. He wants to build a road in the undeveloped rural terrain of traditional Kerala to help further the spice trade. Helping him to fulfil his dream is his faithful servant TK (Rahul Bose) who forms the bridge between the Englishman and the natives. TK has his motives clear. He wants to savour the best of both the worlds, be it the high culture of the burra sahib's world or the family linkages with his tribe. But life cannot be sailed in two boats: that's a truth TK is forced to realise when his sahib's affair with the maid, Sajani (Nandita Das) turns awry. With the freedom struggle building up and Sajani's drastic end to a soured love story threatening to boil over into an us versus them confrontation, the English homestead becomes a seething cauldron. More imortantly, TK gets a taste of his English master's true moral fibre.

Celebrate Independence Day with this artistic celebration of swaraj and nationalist awakening.

Game for Japanese manga on the big screen? For all the little boys out there, this one's just another of those adventure stories, featuring a teen hero who, like the Kung Fu Panda, must find his true potential.

Only then will he be able to save the world from Lord Piccolo, a megalomaniac who dreams of global destruction.

Geeky Goku may be a misfit, with his special powers, but he does manage to find a team that will help him in his dangerous mission. These include a martial arts specialist, Master Roshu (Chow-Yun Fat), a svelte scientist, a cute girl friend and a maverick mercenary. The gang sets out in search of the seven dragonballs, which must be assembled together, before peace reigns. It's an eventful trek, with loads of special effects, much of which are actually second rate.

This one's only for PSP addicts.

How many times has Hollywood revelled in the gangster film? Countless times, with almost every notable actor having tried his hand at essaying the Bonnie and Clyde fable or the Scarface anti-heroics.

And yet, there are still some directors who manage to reinvent the genre, even though the gangster hero's dalliance with crime and his cat-and-mouse brush with the law is something you've seen before.

Director Michael Mann's one such auteur who creates a whole new atmospherics for his period biopic on John Dillinger, the balsy bank robber who plagued the law agencies with his daring heists during the Depression years. Shot in high-definition digital, the film is high on detail and pictoral opulence as it meticulously captures the rise and sudden fall of Dillinger, the simple Indiana farm boy who grew up to become one of Chicago's most famous outlaws. The film is brimming over with scintillating action set pieces which include daring prison breaks, gritty shoot-outs against grand backdrops (forests, streets, grasslands) and high-tension heists with Johnny Depp unleashing his charm on the teller with a sugary: Get me the money, honey.

In fact, Johnny Depp is the heart and soul of the film with his smooth and easy charm and his languid air. He brings to life a fedora-donning outlaw who loves his job and is even quite proud of it. `I rob banks', he openly declares and sweeps the sweet Ms Cottilard off her feet with his don't-give-a-damn attitude and his succinct self-introduction: `I love fast cars, golf, whiskey and you.' In fact, Marion Cottilard, a simple hatcheck girl is the only chink in his armour. Otherwise, there is nothing that can stop our unflappable gunman from leading the good life by ill-gotten means. Not even the dogged FBI agent Melvin Pervis (Christian Bale) who was determined to get Dillinger to the gallows. It's a nerve-wracking battle between the two, with the cop ending up as the loser, most of the times. He does manage to arrest the robber after a daring heist, but slipping out of prison's seems to be child's play for the man who fears nothing.

It is this fearlessness that works as a double edged sword for our anti-hero. On the one hand, it gives us one of the most memorable scenes in a gangster film where the most wanted criminal, Depp walks into the Chicago police headquarters, take a leisurely touristy trip down the rooms, smirks at his pictures on the walls and even asks for the Yankees' score after spotting a bunch of cops intently listening to the radio. Again, in another incident, he brazenly sits in his Buick in the street, while the cops arrest his girlfriend from the apartment in front and quiz her on his whereabouts. They fail to notice his presence, simply because they cannot believe he would be right there in the busiest part of the city. But it is this devil-may-care attitude that ends up as his undoing. For the cops try to close in as he enjoys a Clark Gable gangster flick in a crowded auditorium, minus all cover.

The film is a cinematic treat with its artistic canvas, its fine detailing and its towering portrayal of a real-life bandit by Johnny Depp, an actor who always manages to astound you with his kaleidoscopic skills.

John Woo returns to his Asian roots after a long gap of 17 years. And he returns with a huge reputation to live up to, having carved an enviable niche for himself in Hollywood with films like Mission Impossible, Broken Arrow and Face/Off. Ostensibly, he is the first Asian director to strike gold in mainstream Hollywood, much before Ang Lee mesmerised the West with Sense and Sensibility and Brokeback Mountain.

With Red Cliff, he takes on an ambitious project that ends up as one of the most expensive Chinese productions, mounted at a staggering cost of $80 million. But more than the money, it is the scale of the film that is majestic as it tries to analyse the art of warfare through a period film set in China's contentious past.

Woo sets his film in 208 AD when China was divided into three warring kingdoms. Each kingdom has its own hero, determined to defend territory at all cost. This time however, the Kingdoms of the south and the west come together in order to ward of the advancing armies of General Cao Cao (Zhang Fengyi) who seems to be the mightiest of them all, with an army of 800,000 soldiers. Only Tony Leung and Takeshi Kaneshiro, the brave generals from the other two camps, can act as spoilsport and prevent the power hungry Cao Cao from conquering the Red Cliff, a symbol of the sovereignty of the southern kingdom. But victory doesn't depend on the strength and might of the navy, army and cavalry alone in this copy book case of war; it depends on strategy too, which could empower even a lesser equipped band of warriors. As in the case of our defenders who use the direction of the wind to win an almost no-win battle.

Don't go looking for Zhang Yimou's period epics; nor expect the anti-gravity athleticism of Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon and you might just be mesmerised by John Woo's grandiose battles. But what you will sorely miss is the breathtaking cinematography and the feminine mystique that is so intrinsic to Chinese epical cinema. Of course there is the much touted cinematic debut of model Lin Chiling as Mrs Tony Leung and there is Vicky Zhao playing the feistyPrincess Sun Shan Xiang who infiltrates enemy territory. But, by and large, they remain by-standers in this all-male drama which mostly has one thing to boast about: the chemistry between Tony Leung and Takeshi Kaneshiro.

Part 1 was funny and original. Part 2 is still funny without being original and has a much larger canvas of characters that come tumbling out of history, once the lights are turned off at the Museum.

Night guard, Larry Daley (Ben Stiller) has a rescue mission at hand this time. Some of his friends, which include the heroic Midnight Cowboy, Jedediah Smith (Owen Wilson), have been packaged off to the Smithsonian, now that their original home, the Museum of Natural History is being remodelled. But before he can reinstate the cowboy to his rightful place, Daley must confront new enemies, hungry for power.

These include the lisping Pharaoh (Hank Azaria) with his army of bird-brained warriors and his gang of power-seekers. But remember, Daley has all the good guys on his side. Like Teddy Roosevelt, Rodin's Thinker, Einstein and Abe Lincoln. But the real chutzpah lies with the new recruit in the war of good against evil: adorable Amelia Earhart, the feisty woman who flew the plane across the Pacific. This time, she flies the Wright Brother's stringy machine in another do-or-die mission for the man she's smitten with: Daley of course. This one's silly, yet funny with a roll call of rib-tickling characters pulled out from moth-balled history.

The film is indeed a timely release. It traces the loneliness, anguish and pathos of Michael (Diego Luna), a performer who tries to make a living as a Michael Jackson impersonator in the streets of Paris.

But Michael doesn't only do the moon walk and the crotch clutch before uninterested passers-by. He even lives his life like MJ and shares the same mindscape. Have you ever wanted to have a different face, sing a different song, do a different dance? he asks the viewers, through his make-up and his mask. Hey, is that the impersonator or the original speaking!

Michael however isn't the only imitator here. There is the double of Marilyn Monroe, Charlie Chaplin, Abe Lincoln, James Dean, The Pope, Shirley Temple, Red Riding Hood, Madonna, the Three Stooges....All of them living in a desolate commune in the Scottish highlands, as one great family. And all of them ending up as a bunch of lonely and lost weirdoes hoping to make a living by leading a life that isn't their own. Add to this, a sad and unrequited love story between Michael and Marilyn, a dose of domestic abuse by Chaplin and a delicious sub-plot of flying nuns in a South American hamlet, and you have a delightful tale of dying dreams, crumbling faith and human anguish.

But don't get bogged down by the heavy theme, for Mister Lonely is absolutely zany and wild, with imagery and allegory that borders on the never-before. The film is a visual feast with montages that completely push the frontiers of the creative imagination. Watch Michael riding his bike uphill in slow motion, take a boat ride with Monroe in the cold seas or a nun fall out of a plane and survive: this one's truly for the bold and the innovative who love experimental cinema. Serenade the surreal.

The film was screened in the non-competition section at Cannes and managed to draw a lot of attention due to its leading lady, Asia Argento, for her no-holds-barred portrayal of a hooker who walks the dangerous road to money and power.

Asia's rendition of Sandra, the sensuous woman who dreams of setting up her own club in Beijing and escaping from the grime of Parisian low life, is a character that's both cold and vulnerable; dangerous and defenceless. With her tattoos and her high heels, she rides rough shod over anyone who dares to come in her way, only to end up being a pawn herself. For, though she may have no compunctions teaching her ex-lover (Michael Madsen) a lesson, she becomes a liability for her current lover (Carl Ng), when his wife learns of their illicit liaison. On the run, for a crime she committed on the behest of her lover, she finds herself alone and hunted in the hostile streets of Hong Kong. Will our street smart street-walker survive, like Vortex, the sci-fi heroine she once created on a sci-fi website? Or will it be guns and gore, all the way for super Sandra?

The clock keeps ticking in this taut thriller that doesn't really boast of anything original, other than Ms Asia and her antics.

Just one more year to go. Understandably, there's so much to do for young Mr Potter and his pals, now in their sixth year at Hogwarts. Before they enter their final year, they have to find ways to wind up their save-the-world mission by wiping out the Dark Lord and his devious ambition. Because, when the seventh year begins, it would be just do or die, with no time for deliberations, explorations, inventions.

Hence, there is an overriding sense of urgency in the penultimate film, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince which moves at breakneck speed from the opening sequence itself. The spooky death-eaters rise from the hell beneath and surround the dimly-lit world, as Hogwarts prepares to open for a new term. Surprisingly, Harry doesn't seem to be in a tearing hurry this time and prefers to spend some quality time in a coffee shop, getting harmlessly flirty with a saucy waitress while he reads a newspaper that anoints him as the Chosen One. But hey, Harry's got no time for birds and bees, does he? So enter Professor Dumbledore (Michael Gammbon) and his homily on how the clock's ticking, hopes dimming and Voldermort's grinning, as he gets closer to victory.

There's something about Sandra Bullock that makes her instantly connect with you. Ever since her clumsy, nervous rookie act against the cocky Sylvester Stallone in Demolition Man and her er-um-I-can't bravado in Speed, with super hero Keanu Reeves, Sandra has carried forth her title of Ms Congeniality with an unparalleled charisma.

And unlike larger-than-life actresses like Julia Roberts, Angelina Jolie, Sandra's appeal has been more of the lovable girl-next-door types. One who can sweep you off your feet with her understated charm and restrained chic. Here, she may have a role that demands her to do a retake of Meryl Streep's despicable boss act in The Devil Wears Prada, but she does it with a signature flourish that is hers alone.

Top editor Margaret Tate is hailed as a witch and a terrorist by almost all her employees. and not for nothing. For Margaret is the archetypal corporate climber who would brook no interference in her ascent to the top job. Even if it means a deportation to Canada, since she is an illegal immigrant in New York, now that her visa has expired. Margaret finds a way out of this maze too. She proposes to her assistant, Andrew (Ryan Reynolds) and lures him into a marriage of convenience with the prospect of a promotion. Needless to say, Andrew hates her and longs for her to come under a cab....But ah! love works in mysterious ways, doesn't it. And love stories are always such fun for die-hard romantics.

All it takes for the quarrelsome duo to change into a real couple is a weekend trip to Andrew's home in distant Alaska, where Sandra realises the worth of a family hearth. Now that's something she had forgotten in the rat race in Manhattan's concrete jungle where there was no prospective mom-in-law to serve her breakfast in bed and no granma-in-law to teach her the wild rituals of nature. Also, there was no Andrew to save her from the cold Alaskan waters and share her lonely musings in the dead of night.

It may be unabashedly sentimental and predictably romantic, yet The Proposal manages to win you over with its sassy script and showstopper Sandra. Feel the butter melt and the popcorn crackle in this breezy love sonnet.

The franchise carries on showcasing its brilliant art work, its warm and vibrant characters and its straight-from-the-heart story of team spirit and survival, of not only the fittest, but the weakest too.

Yes, Ice Age 3 is a fitting sequel to the animal saga that turned out to be a moving human parable when it was first released in 2002.

It's funny without being slapstick. It's comedy, yet completely inventive. The Hangover is one of the smartest laugh fests spilling out from the Hollywood stables, after a long-long time. And the fact that it manages to actually piece together a bizarre story about recognisable characters trapped in absolutely unrecognisable circumstances only goes to prove that this is one of the zaniest screenplays too in recent times. Can you think of a plausible reason behind the presence of a roaring tiger, a bawling baby, a chicken, a broken tooth, a pierced belly button, a vanished inmate from an expensive hotel suite in Las Vegas? Writers Jon Lucas and Scott Moore can, with a flourish and a panache that manages to put all the improbable loose ends together in a cogent it-happened-one-night adventure.

Doug (Justin Bartha) is all set to marry his girlfriend. But before he settles down to husband-hood, he decides to celebrate his bachelor's party with his best buddies, dentist Stu (Ed Helms) and school teacher Phil (Bradley Cooper) in Las Vegas. At the last minute he decides to invite his fiance's brother, Alan (Zach Galifianakis) too. Nothing wrong with that, except that Alan's some kind of a sociopath -- weird, yet adorable, all at the same time. The foursome book themselves an expensive villa at Caesar's Palace, not before Alan has asked the receptionist whether Caesar actually lived there! After that, it's straight to the terrace, where they toast each other with shots of Jagermeister and then wake up the next morning, with no memory of the night revelry. All they know is that Stu has a broken tooth, Phil a hospital tag, Alan a pierced belly button and Doug reported as missing. Adding to their woes is the crying baby in the cupboard, the roaring tiger in the bathroom and a police car that has replaced their Mercedes.

Any explanations anyone? Before the bride panics, the friends must find the groom. It's a search that leads them to a sweet hooker (Heather Graham) who says she's Stu's wife, a naked Chinese gangster who wants 80k, a belligerent Mike Tyson who wants his stolen tiger back and a final showdown in the Mojave desert. Needless to say, the journey ends up as a therapeutic exercise for all the players who return as better adjusted individuals, ready to cope with routine in a revitalised way.

A great fun ride, The Hangover introduces a whole new bunch of talent to Hollywood, specially Zach, the nerd. Don't miss it.

Walt Disney have always been the pioneer in animation features. And Bolt does not disappoint with its state-of-the-art animation and its drmatic voice-overs, specially by John Travolta as Bolt, the super dog, and Miley Cyrus as Penny, his adolescent mistress.

Bolt has been living an unnatural life ever since his puppy dog days. Almost like the Truman Show, he too has been bred to believe the unreal is real; that the world actually has an evil green-eyed man (Malcolm McDowell) who is hell bent on harming his `person', Penny; that the only way he can protect her is with his special stare, his special punch and his special bark that turns everything, including tanks and copters, into smithereens. Bolt's method acting is the only way the TRPs of the popular television show will keep on rising, believe the producers and the directors. Hence, it's no home, no chasing balls, no goofy walks in the park for our poor little star pooch.

But all this only until Bolt gets separated from Penny and finds himself transported from LA to New York. Then, out there in the rough and tumble of life, he learns that a growling stomach means he's hungry, which means he must beg for food. Naturally, these are lesson of life that come with great difficulty, only after he befriends an alley cat who tells him he is ordinary, not special. But, she also tells him how ordinary can be special too....

Now this one's a fun film for the entire family, with little lessons on love and friendship you can carry home with you. Lessons you learn from a dog, a cat and a hamster.

Poor Christian Bale. If the Dark Knight overshadowed him in his last outing as Batman, then here, it is man-machine, Marcus Wright (Sam Worthington) who manages to walk away with more applause as compared to John Connor, the savior of the human race in this indeterminate war between man and machine. Is Wright the new Terminator who switches sides, like Arnold Schwarzennegar did in the earlier sequels? Is he a friend or foe to Connor and his kin? Go find out, but only after an explosion of in-your-face action that keeps the clock ticking in this apocalyptic war that doesn't seem so distant anymore.

X-men fans have often wondered why Wolverine, their favourite mutant is such a brooding, unsmiling character, sporting an almost natural revulsion for the lighter side of life. And love. In all his earlier three outings as Logan/Wolverine, the man with the metal claws, Hugh Jackman, has perfected the role of the angst-ridden savior who prefers to doggedly follow his mission, minus all distractions. And the fact that he has no memory of his past only makes his detachment more pronounced.

It's time to stop wondering now. For director Gavin Hood goes back to the nineteenth century to trace the origins of Wolverine's super powers along with with his weltanshaung (read worldly despair). Now Gavin Hood's the Oscar-winning South African director who won the Best Foreign Film Award for Tsosti, his film on juvenile gangs in Johannesburg. Naturally, he brings to Hollywood his native style of gritty narration and sepia imagery that formed the hallmark of Tsotsi. All this, without abandoning the extravagance and high-adrenalin action quintessential to Hollywood blockbuster fare. End result? A visually overpowering, high testosterone prequel to Marvel Comic's popular super hero who incidentally has been voted the number one comic book hero in a recent poll.

Both Anne Hathaway and Kate Hudson have definitely seen better days, better scripts and better roles. Nevertheless, they do try to enliven this low IQ comedy with their antics as best friends-turned-bitter foes.

Anne, a school teacher, is the gentler one while Kate is a feisty lawyer who always like to be ahead of the rest. The two have always wanted to get married at the Plaza, ever since they witnessed a dream wedding as kids in the upmarket Manhattan hotel. Nothing wrong with that, except that the wedding planner (Candice Bergen) fixes both the weddings for the same date at the same venue. So who's going to change the date or the venue? Not Kate, who never likes to come second. Not Anne too, who doesn't want to be a pushover any more. So let the war begin....

movie

Okay, so you've seen the girls doing a bit of time travel in films like 13 Going on 30 and Freaky Friday. And you've seen Tom Hanks too play boy-turned-man in Big. But you actually won't mind 17 Again, despite the familiar story line, because there's something sweet and so very old-fashioned about a dad (Matthew Perry) who becomes a high school hero (Zac Efron) and tries to tutor his kids (now his classmates) in the ways of the world.

Yes, Perry ostensibly slips back into his youth in order to rewrite his life's story which seems to have hit dead end. His promotion is denied, divorce is round the corner and his kids don't respect him. Maybe, he can escape the bitter truth if he goes back to the best years of his life and makes a different choice. But time travel only helps him re-build his bridges once again with his estranged family, despite the awkwardness of situations where his daughter flips for him and he kisses his 30-something wife.

Harmless fun.

A few weeks ago we got to see the srious side of Jackie Chan as the unsmiling, revenge-thirsty Hong Kong cop in New Police Story. This week, he returns again in his unsmiling avtar as Steelhead, the simple Chinese F.O.B who lands in downtown Tokyo (Shinjuku), takes refuge with the rest of the Chinese immigrants living in Tokyo's seamy and slummy areas and ends up as their savior. Steelhead actually came to Tokyo looking for his girlfriend, but before he can find her, he must raise the battle cry for the dignity and honour of the exploited illegal Chinese immigrants. It's a battle which sees him locking horns, first with the Taiwanese underworld and then with the warring Yakuza, after he saves the life of one of them.
Poor, love-lorn Steelhead. The man he saved turns out to be his girl friend's husband and makes him an offer he cannot refuse. He promises him legal status if he kills a few rival gangsters for him. Now that's a request he can hardly refuse, specially since his ex still looks longingly at him.

It's a hard-hitting action drama, with some gritty and gut-wrenching violence. And surprisingly, you don't actually miss the buffoon you grew to love in the Rush Hour series since Chan has successfully changed his colours to a more morally ambiguous and sombre grey. Go for the difference.

Space has indeed been the final frontier for Hollywood's grandiose drama. But, while most film academicians may nominate the George Lucas Star War series as the mother of all space adventures, Star Trek too glitters in a galaxy not far behind. The time and space transcending bond between Captain Kirk and pointy-eared Spock are truly the stuff legends are made of. As are their sundry adventures which see them piloting the peace-keeping armada of the USS Enterprise from one planet to the other, taming rebels and adding friends to the intergalactic Federation.

The film was meant to reinvigorate the franchise which had gained popularity in the form of a television series with actors William Shatner and Leonard Nimoy creating cult characters of the two legendary space gladiators, Captain Kirk and Mr Spock. Reinvigorate, it does. But even more than that, it creates a spectacle that scores both in terms of its sheer visual opulence and its vibrant characters. On the one hand, there is the shock and awe factor which has the viewer sitting back and watching black holes swallow up whole planets along with a gravity defying physical combat on the deck of a hurtling space ship. On the other, there is the crackling relationship between a rakish, rebellious twenty-something Kirk (Christopher Pine) and the clinically logical, yet emotional Vulcan-human Spock (Zachary Quinto) which keeps you glued to your seat. You can't seem to get enough of their dushmani-dosti business.

movie

Based on a popular Korean film -- which was re-made in Hindi too, as Ugly aur Pagli -- My Sassy Girl is a sweet little entertainer for all you diehard romantics out there. Get mushy with a love story that keeps going astray and steers clear of the beaten track because of its ditzy heroine who feels normal is truly boring.

Nice guy Charlie Bellow (Jesse Bradford) ends up saving a tipsy young girl in the subway and finds himself doing the very savior thing again and again. For Jordan Roark (Elisha Cuthbert) isn't an ordinary girl. She likes to live life dangerously, outrageously and drunkenly. But opposites always do attract, don't they. So Charlie gives up his ordered existence and begins to live life crazily too, in order to keep up with his enigmatic girl friend. So what if he ends up almost drowning in the sea or stuffing letters in a time capsule. Sassy girl friends are meant to be understood with the heart, not the head.

Jesse is charming, Elisha is cute and their zany affair keeps the reels rolling in an unusual love story with the usual heartbreak and happy home-comings.

Director Ron Howard outclasses author Dan Brown, this time at least. For all those Dan Brown fans who raised mumblings of discontent after the cinematic version of Da Vinci Code failed to live up to the book, there's sweet relief this week. For the film version of Angels and Demons is definitely a page turner, unput-downable to the very core. It takes you on an unbridled roller-coaster ride through the intrigues of Vatican city, trying to uncover what goes on not only behind the pristine walls of the legendary Sistine Chapel but also the other historic churches that become dungeons of hell, when misused.

Professor Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks) is summarily pulled out of the swimming pool by the Vatican police and airjacked to Vatican City after the untimely death of one of the most progressive popes who didn't actually see a conflict between science and faith. The Pope's death is just part of the problem, since Langdon must find out who has kidnapped the four potential papal candidates, known as the Preferati and placed a bomb in one of the sundry churches that dot the city. Now that's not an ordinary bomb, as the beautiful Ms Vettori (Ayelet Zurer), a scientist from the CERN lab, tells us. It's a bomb made up of anti-matter (remember, the God particle), stolen from the Hadron Collider and can wipe out the historic city that rules almost one billion Christians, the world over.

movie

Thai director Prancha Pinkaew has presented before the world a Thai answer to oriental martial arts by popularising Muay Thai through his high octane action films, Ong Bak and Tom Yum Goong which went on to make an international star of the hero, Tony Jaa. This time, he sets aside Jaa for newcomer Jija Yanin Vismitananda, a sprightly young girl who kick-boxes her way through the film, leaving you completely awe-struck.

Zen isn't an ordinary kid. The doctors have told her mother she has a slow brain and needs special attention. The mother, who happens to be the wife of a gangster, gives up her life of crime and goes into hiding to take care of her child. Living in a strange neighbourhood, she brings in an orphan boy into her family, who ends up as her daughter's caring brother. Zen seems to have a yen for chocolate and for chopsocky. Spending most of her time watching action films, she picks up her kick-boxing skills from the small screen and goes out into the cruel world to collect money for her dying mother's treatment. Time for one thrilling fight to follow another as the film throws up the most unlikely grandmaster of them all: a slip of a girl who wears pedal-pushers and holds a rag doll.

Go for the adrenalin-pumping action sequences which are pure art, in terms of their perfect hand-foot-eye coordination. The film reminds you of Tarantino's hand combat tricks in the Kill Bill series.

Journalist Jennifer Lopez plays action hero as she tries to solve a case that takes her from the US to Mexico, where she must investigate why the murder of almost 400 women has remained unsolved till date. She takes the help of her former lover and colleague, Antonio Banderas, who runs a local paper of his own in the Mexican outback. A gritty film that keeps the tension rolling, this one's for Jennifer Lopez fans.

This Dutch film has won the special jury award at Cannes and is heavily recommended for two reasons. First, because it is a text book case to show what cinematography is all about. Watch the director reinvent the function of the camera in cinema from the very first shot which captures the skyscape from a static long shot as it passes from darkness to dawn. Accompanying the passage of stars to the first sun rays is the changing audio track, which once again captures the natural cadence of a countryside where the crickets and the frogs give way to the cows and the cocks. The director repeats the prolonged shot at the end of the film, only this time, dusk turns to darkness, and leaves you completely mesmerised. Never seen the camera serenade nature like this before. In fact, the entire film is an artistic compendium of interesting long shots which langorously bring out the trauma of an extra-marital affair on a simple, god fearing family that believes in love and togetherness.

Secondly, the film is notable for its extreme simplicity and its minimalism as it captures the mess that love can be, if it happens at the wrong time, the wrong place. Middle aged Johan falls in love with Maria and is irresistibly drawn towards her, despite being fervently devoted to his wife Esther and his family of six kids. He tells his wife of his extra-marital affair and promises to find a solution to the tangle. But Johan takes too long to make his choice between the two women he loves. So much so, his silent, mostly uncomplaining wife falls prey to her grief, leaving Johan and his mistress, both heartbroken. It takes a miracle to set nature -- and the family -- back on its course. Till then, you have been wowed by this offbeat experience.

This one's strictly for film buffs who like uplifting cinema that's off the beaten track.

The popularity of Asterix comes second only to Harry Potter. Small wonder then, the comic books about the two wild-boar loving, indomitable Gaul heroes have sales figures measuring up to almost 250,000 copies. After two live action features, starring Gerard Depardieu, the film returns to animation as it traces the adventures of Asterix (Paul Giamatti) and Obelisk who have been assigned a thankless task: they must make a warrior out of the city-dude, Justforkiks (Sean Astin) who is essentially a cowardly teenager, with little respect for Gaulish ways. He however seems to be perfect experimental material for the Vikings from the north who want to see how fear can give wings to people. The Viking's chief hopes to scare the lily-livered teen and learn how he flys. But for his own feisty daughter, Abba, who seems to hell bent of unleashing a feminist movement of her own. Neat fun, specially for Asterix fans.

Summer is always the time of animation, when kid's become the prime target audience. Igor may not be the liveliest animation flick around, nevertheless it has an appeal that is reminiscent of Tim Burton's dark cinema canvases. Understandable, since the film mostly deals with ugliness and has for its hero the not-so-winsome Igor, a hunchback who is treated as a menial servant by his master, Dr Glickenstein. But every slave has his day, and so does Igor when his master dies while preparing for the grand show, the Evil Science Fair. Igor seizes the opportunity and creates his own hulking monster, Eva (Molly Shannon), hoping to beat the living daylights out of everyone with his own Frankenstein's bride. Ironically, Eva turns out to be a gem of a monster who dreams of becoming a great actor rather than a man-eater. But that's a secret Igor's adversaries don't know, as they try to steal Eva from her master.

Will the hunchback and his bride find love? Go visit the fairy tale, which is more fun for adults than for kids.

This is a remake of a 1957 western about a confrontation between a ruthless outlaw (Russell Crowe) and an upright rancher (Christian Bale) where the chemistry between the two ethically opposed men grows from enmity to respect. It's absolute vintage fare, demanding a dekko, specially since both the actors -- Crowe and Bale -- pitch in powerhouse performances.
Impoverished cattle rancher Dan Evans is all set to lose his ranch but can do little to fight off the land grabbers, much to the discomfiture of his young son (Logan Lerman). When the town captures infamous outlaw Ben Wade (Russell Crowe), he offers to escort him to the 3:10 train to the Yuma prison where the hangman's noose awaits the flashy criminal. Dan may have lost a leg in the civil war, nevertheless, he is still a sharpshooter; but more importantly, he needs the fee of $200 for services rendered, since this would help him feed his family. Wade offers him inducements beyond his imagination, but Dan is an honest man. And Dan is a brave man too, unperturbed by Wade's brutal gang that's hell bent on freeing their leader, even if it means killing everyone else.

Great atmosphere, gritty drama, gruelling chemistry: this one's a cracker of a film. Don't miss it.

For all those of you out there who have created an altar in your music room for albums like The Evil That Men Do, Charlotte the Harlot, Can I Play Madness, The Number of the Beast and are often seen swooning with numbers like Judas Be My Guide, Flash of the Blade and the rest...this is truly nirvana time. Go grab your front row seats for this string of exquisitely recorded concerts of the heavy metal band that seems to be immortal. Yes, Iron Maiden, the English cult band that came into being on Christmas 1975, under the able stewardship of Steve

Harris, may have been around for more than thirty years. Yet, it's popularity hasn't diminished and surprisingly, the band has managed to find new fans, generation after generation. So that, in a single family, you could have mom and dad headbanging with their teenagers and tweenagers too.
In 2008, the band undertook one of its longest musical tours entitled `Somewhere Back in Time', spanning the entire globe in 45 days. They travelled from India to Australia, Japan, America and South America in their customised plane called the Ed Force One. More importantly, the plane was piloted by lead vocalist, Bruce Dickinson, who literally turns out to be a high-flyer, both on and off the stage. This is the first time the band allowed a film crew to be with them for such a prolonged period, enabling the interviewers to capture them both at work and during their free time. So that, in one frame, you have the group sending its fans into mass hysteria with their high-decibel performances, and in the other, you have them chilling out, either with a sweaty game of tennis or teeing off on the golf course. Sometimes, the camera even intrudes their work space and pans on Steve Harris as he pens the lyrics and plays anchorman to the group.

Needless to say, the film lights up, mostly in the concerts which are shot in high definition surround sound: enough to send heavy metal buffs into a rhapsody. Also endearing are the encounters with fans, specially in South America, where the band is treated with godlike devotion. Sometimes, you do miss the `real' story, since the film is such a hunky-dory depiction of the motley group. No drugs, no rivalries, no creative quirks...just squeaky clean.

Go, join the headbanger's ball, all you heavy metal fans out there.

The scary summer vacation flick is back. A bunch of college kids take a break after their exams and rent a cabin in a forest for a camping trip. Predictably, the holiday turns out to be a nightmare after the hyperactive teens bump off a scary intruder who seems to be inflicted with a bloody virus, with blood and pus pouring out from his body. Of course, that's just the beginning of their end, as one by one, they fall prey to the deadly virus which seems to be determined to bleed them to death.

Watch it, if you can handle the preponderance of red -- oodles and oodles of blood dripping from the screen, with scenes of stomach-churning muck that's definitely not meant for the faint-hearted.

Jackie Chan takes a break from Hollywood comedies and returns to home ground: Hong Kong action films. And it isn't a bad home-coming at all, even though the film may be somewhat dated.

The perils and woes of the Hong Kong police department are almost similar to the cop crunching tales of the NYPD. Ask Inspector Wing (Jackie Chan), who was forced to hit the bottle when one of his cases went kaput and took a violent turn. Chan lost four of his colleagues in a brutal encounter with a teen gang, led by the malevolent juvenile delinquent, Joe (Daniel Wu). Joe bumps off the entire SWAT team in an abandoned warehouse and leaves Chan as the anguished witness to the horrific crime. A year later, a guilt-ridden Chan is forced to abandon the bottle, don his uniform again and swear revenge, when he sees the internet abuzz with a video game, based on the cop slaughter. Aiding his resurrection is the motivation given by his new partner (Nicholas Tse), who seems to have his own axe to grind with Joe and his boys.

Enter, the angry kick boxer who seems to have shed his comedian act behind for some real explosive stuff. Watch out for regular Chan fare, which includes some dizzy action sequences and high-octane chases that never seem to tire the action junkie in you. Gird up for the hustle in Hong Kong's crowded streets, for the fifty-year-old action hero is still rippling with energy.

Very early in the film, Pierce Brosnan describes marriage as a mild kind of infection, somewhat akin to flu or chicken pox and thanks destiny for never having caught this infection himself. Get the picture. Ira Sach's taut thriller is a no-holds-barred look into the seamier side of this hallowed institution where there's so little that so many people know about their spouses. Psychologists and marriage counsellors mostly ascribe the success of this institution to two main factors: secrets and lies.

Set against the genteel 1940s, this comedy of misdemeanours unfolds through a treacherous web of adultery, deceit and murder. Middle-aged Chris Cooper lives out the American dream with his beautiful wife, Patricia Clarkson, who has proved to be the perfect wife through all the tumultuous years of settling in and settling down. Life seems to be on song for this happily married couple, until Cooper lifts the veils off the chinks in the armour. The hitherto dutiful husband has actually been involved in an adulterous relationship with the gentle and uber feminine widow, Rachel McAdams and wants to opt out of his cold and formal marriage. Now that's not an easy situation for conscience-stricken Cooper who has two problems. First, he respects his wife too much to leave her hurting with the tag of a divorcee and second, he has Pierce Brosnan, a completely rakish philanderer friend who falls in love with Cooper's girl friend and wants her for himself. So, on the one hand, you have husband Cooper brewing a complicated plot which involves killing his wife, to spare her the agony of heartbreak and divorce -- a kind of mercy killing. And on the other, you have Brosnan deviously trying to abort the illicit love story and kick start his own with the platinum blonde widow with the irresistible scarlet pout.

The film is a gripping insight into the evil that often tinges adult emotions and unfolds like a languorous thriller, where danger always seems to be lurking round the corner. While Chris Cooper is always a delight to watch with his ability to touch rare depths in a character -- he retains your sympathy, even while plotting his wife's murder -- it is Pierce Brosnan who boldly walks out of the shadow of James Bond. Another successful attempt to break the Bond-age after The Tailor of Panama.

History often seems to be more interesting when viewed through the eyes of a child. Remember Life is Beautiful which re-visited the holocaust in a completely new dimension through the experiences of a young boy. Well, this time, it is the tumultuous 1970s in Brazil, when two simultaneous forces were gaining ground. On the one hand, there was Pele taking Brazil forward towards a World Cup victory. On the other, was a vibrant underground communist movement working towards the overthrow of the prevailing dictatorship. It's this heady cocktail of football and politics that forms the backdrop of the film which focuses on the attempts of eight-year-old Mauro to survive a year away from his home and his parents.

In order to escape torture and arrest, Mauro's activist parents leave him at his grandfather's house in a Jewish neighbourhood in downtown Sao Paulo, promising to return after a long vacation. Little do they know that the grandfather has died and their son has nowhere to go. Unless he consents to live with grandad's grumpy old neighbour (Germano Haiut), who doesn't seem too fond of kids, specially non-Jewish ones, and eats fish for breakfast. Here, in strange environs, the little boy has nothing to fall back upon except his passion for football, the growing friendship with the feisty little Hanna who lives in the same building, the hope that his parents will return and the changing currents in the bustling streets below, where political unrest is keeping pace with World Cup fervour. But hey, there's also the growing bond between his grumpy guardian and him: the heart-tugging keynote of the film which scores heavily in restraint and sensitivity.

Watch it for its alluring recreation of the life and times of the ordinary Brazilian who attains nirvana with Pele's magical footwork and for its powerful performances.

Written and directed by Julie Delpy, the film showcases the multi-faceted French actress in a whole new light. Specially since she manages to create an engaging urban comedy of manners that reminds you of Woody Allen's Manhattan dramas about verbally-charged, dysfunctional couples.

Jake (Adam Goldberg) and Marion (Julie Delpy) have been living together in New York for almost two years, sharing the highs, the lows and the in-betweens. Now, it's time to add some new vigour in their sagging relationship. The two take a trip to Europe and round it off in Paris, where the couple spend two days with Marion's parents and friends. Ostensibly, there are no great dramatic moments. But that doesn't matter for the film is a witty insight on emotional bonding between two culturally different people. Brimming over with delightful one-liners on clash of cultures, gender differences, sexual mores, the film is a charmer.

Watch it. It's like a breath of fresh air.

It's 1985. America and Russia are exploding with rage. The world is threatened with a nuclear war. And amidst all the fear of annihilation, President Nixon bans super hero activity in the US. In case you are confused, this is somewhat a mythical America, where as the film insists, both Superman and God exist and yes, they are Americans. So we have a bunch of masked crusaders, running around in pre-historic batmobiles, capes and hoods, trying to help the US government to save the world from catastrophe. Trouble erupts when one of the older masked crusaders -- the comedian (Jeffrey Dean Morgan) -- is murdered and his colleague, Rorschach (Jackie Earle Hailey), discovers a government plot to assassinate all super heroes to prevent anarchy.

movie

Here's what a strike can do to your film schedule. It can have you end up in an audi, seeing a film that wasn't even considered good enough to be released on the regular circuit in the US. It went straight to DVD, a fate that almost met Slumdog Millionaire, before the encored Toronto festival screening told its producers they had a gold mine in their hands.

Well, My Mom's New Boyfriend may be nowhere near Slumdog Millionaire, in terms of quality, character and originality. Nevertheless, it isn't completely dispensable too. Blame it on the eternal charm of Meg Ryan, who still retains the mesmeric twinkle in her eyes, despite her heavy cosmetic surgery. Or else on the debonair machismo of beefcake Banderas who is watchable, even if he bumbles. But the truth is you actually don't get bored in this mindless caper which has a son spying on his mom on the behest of the government. Come on, it's brain dead, we know. But so are most Hindi film comedies, which we so passionately love.

So keep your thinking caps away and settle down for the silly season. When FBI agent Henry (Colin Hanks) left his mom, Marty (Meg Ryan) for a secret assignment, she was just like any ole mom: obese, ungainly, uninterested in the opposite sex and completely dependent on her son for everything. Three years later, he returns home, only to find a young hottie sunbathing in his backyard. Holy smoke! Is that the matronly matriach, Marty? Yes she is. Mom's had a complete make over, taken hold of her body and her life, gone on a spiritual trip around the world and found her inner soul. Nothing wrong with that, except that this new inner soul seems to love men and Henry must reluctantly learn to live with his mom's boyfriends. Now that's quite hard, specially since he's brought his fiancee (Selma Blair) home too and Marty's new boyfriend, Tommy (Antonio Banderas) turns out to be an international art thief who figures on the FBI's Wanted list.

It's time for the gags to begin when FBI agent, Henry is put on the case and asked to nab the thief, by spying on his mother. Needless to say, it's a job that Harry hates and sees him graduating from disapproving son to reluctant detective. Definitely not the best from biggies like Banderas and Meg Ryan, but good enough for a timepass dekko.

The land of John Woo and Jackie Chan isn't famous, not for nothing. Hong Kong action films have quite a cult following, even in Hollywood, specially since their stunts daringly stand up to the best of the west. Invisible Target lives upto to the reputation from the very start where a daring heist of an armoured vehicle almost blows up the entire screen into smithereens. And before you can see the shards of glass settling down, there are some more deafening explosions and crackling kick butt antics that shatter some more glass. This time in tons and mountains!

The film literally keeps running and kicking its way on screen as three young cops try to nab a gang of robbers, led by the dashing Tien (Jacky Wu Jing), the evil mastermind who happened to kill one of the cop's fiancee as collateral damage. The cop trio also includes Jackie Chan's son, Jaycee Chan who has yet to find his groove. Of course, he does match the other two (Nicholas Tse and Shawn Yue) in their super stunts as they leap off unimaginable heights and survive all odds -- bombs, bullets, collisions, car chases.

Great escape in times of drought. Go for it.

Falling in love may be the easiest thing in life. But what comes after -- commitment, fidelity, compromise -- isn't that easy at all. Based on Philip Roth's novel, The Dying Animal, Elegy is a moving lament to a lost chance of love, life and longing. It is an intellectually stirring critique of modern man's fear of commitment, even as it lays bare the more basic need for a no-strings-attached sexual bonding.

David Kepesh (Ben Kingsley) is a middle-aged professor who is immensely popular with his art and literature class due to his erudition. But Kepesh likes to keep it light and uncomplicated always. He lives alone in his rambling Manhattan apartment, with his collection of Goya and Kafka and the only meaningful human contact he has is with his poet friend and his mistress (Patricia Clarkson) who visits him occasionally, for a heady night of wine and passion. Having divorced his wife, he has a messy relationship with his only son and generally keeps his students at bay. Until he meets Consuela (Penelope Cruz), the beautiful Cuban student, who seems to have walked straight out of a Goya canvas with her striking good looks, aristocratic frame and probing mind. The art historian can barely resist this work of art and seduces her into his bedroom with his intellectual discussions. The relationship grows from mere carnal desire and threatens to last a lifetime, but for David's phobia of total emotional surrender and his fear of the yawning age gap between them. A heart-broken Consuela walks out of his life when she realises there isn't a happily-ever-after for them, while David tries his best to turn back to his isolation. Doesn't work, specially since Consuella comes back, with the threat of impermanence once again...

The film is essentially an aesthetically satisfying experience which touches upon the contemporary problem of urban disconnect, where long term relationships are gradually being replaced by ephemeral one-night-stands. Watch it for the rich fabric and the intense chemistry between Ben Kingsley and Penelope Cruz who set the screen on fire with their passion and anguish.

First things first. Watch this film only in an auditorium that allows you to enjoy the 3-D animation effect. And that's because watching an alien fly right into you, a fireball falling onto you and a car driving onto the screen from behind you shocks and awes like never before. Definitely not like Chota Chetan, India's first tryst from 2-D to 3-D.

Truly, the highlight of Dreamwork's new animation film is its stylised 3-D effect which creates a spectacle of the moving image. It catapults you right into the vortex of the action and almost makes you a participant as you duck, lunge back and jump start each time the brightly animated screen reaches out to pull, pummel or petrify.

movie

Diesel power explodes once again, after having vroomed off into anonymity for the last eight years. The alluring speed devil, Dominic Torreto (Vin Diesel), who became a cult figure in the first Fast and Furious, turned his back to the two sequels that followed (2Fast 2Furious and Tokyo Drift) due to fee problems. The franchise lost its zing and Vin almost vanished from the screen. So, naturally, the two had to get together again and create grease lightnin' once more.

movie

It takes the death of Julia Roberts, an archetypal home-maker, to bring together her dysfunctional family. Julia, the perfect mother and wife, lived her life, bridging the gap between her husband (Willem Dafoe) and her son (Ryan Reynolds). But she failed to smooth out the differences between them. The father was too strict and the son too rebellious. Hence, the negative vibes, which continued even during the funeral, when Reynolds tried his best to run away from his grief by running after fireflies, fishing with his young cousins or making-out with his separated wife (Carrie Ann Moss). His only confidante was his aunt (Emily Watson). But here again, there seems to be more than meets the eye...

You need to hang on patiently to watch the animosity being replaced by family bonhomie as all the skewed equations are set right. Of course, you end up missing Ms Roberts who's done away too soon. Watch out for a feisty show by Emily Watson as the mysterious Aunt Jane.

Music has the magical power, not only to make a star out of the errant folks, but also to heal conflict and bring feuding families together. That's the message of this small, grainy little film that doesn't boast much in terms of style, but hangs together by a frail thread: its story of the underdog having his day.

Rob (Omarion Grandberry) is the proverbial underdog who must escape Harlem because the mob is after him. His worried mother sends him off to distant Puerto Rico, the land of Jennifer Lopez, where the errant son not only re-connects with his enstranged father, but also manages to pioneer a new form of music with his step brother. They call it Reggaeton: an ecelctic mix of hip hop, rap and Carribean angst, which becomes an instant hit as a youthful language of protest.

A hipster ode to the family, this one's a time-pass tryst with street kids and their survivor spirit.

The film scores heavily in terms of topicality. Not only does it present the banker as a brand new villain, it also blows the lid off the covert funding of arms and terrorism by organisations that transcend all national and political boundaries. So, you have a bank that may be based in Luxemburg, but it funds the purchase of arms for both the Israelis and the Palestinians, apart from being the money power behind all third world anarchy. It's left to Clive Owen, an interpol officer and Naomi Watts, a bold district attorney, to put an end to their nefarious activities.

The plot may be tend to get lost in the details, as you try and keep pace with Owen and Watts who cross continents in their pursuit of the shadowy bank operatives. But the film boasts of two fine action sequences that leave you asking for more. The first is an extended gun fight in the Guggenheim Museum in New York, where the magnificent architecture plays a compelling role in the violence. And the second is a chase on the roof of a building in Istanbul, surrounded by picturesque mosques, with the muezzin's cry in the backdrop.

Watch it for a Bourne Identity feel and for a steely performance by the rugged Clive Owen.

The film is a must for all educationists as it brings to light a whole new system of education where interactivity is the key word. Based on the best-selling autobiographical novel by Francois Begaudeau, a teacher who plays the lead role in the film, The Class creates a whole new equation between the four walls of a classroom. One, where democracy rules, instead of the hiearchical teacher-taught relationship that currently prevails in most schools.

Francois starts a new term with great hope in a downmarket school that has a multi-ethnic group of students. He encourages his students to ask questions, express themselves and create self-portraits to help him understand them better. But are these kids ready to accept change? More importantly, can they handle the freedom to question and disobey or will the school discipline go for a toss in this new culture of `equality'.

An intelligent film that went on to win sundry prizes at international film festivals, The Class leaves you with the burning question: Time to overhaul our archaic education system too?

Ready for one more ode to the family? Reese and Vince are an upmarket couple who have been together for three years without having popped the question about marriage. And that's because they don't want to end up like their families, grounded by domestic responsibilities, loyalties, fraternities...For them, it's more important to go scuba diving in Fiji than spending Christmas with their divorced parents and squabbling siblings. Naturally then, they aren't too happy when an unwarranted fog cancels their their vacation plans and forces them to spend four Christmases with four different sets of family.

If Vince's parivar boasts of a bunch of nerdish brothers who still want to play tug-of-war with their long-lost brother, unmindful of broken noses and bruised eyes, then Reese must learn how to baby-sit her sister's kids and grapple with her mother's eccentricities. Of course, the duo have decided to escape as soon as things get out of hand, but Christmas is a strange festival. With so much warmth and good cheer all around, it almost always ends up bringing enstranged people together. It doesn't take long before the new age couple is talking about old-fashioned values and dreaming of kids, home and a family of their own.

What's missing in this film is both warmth and humour. The gags are too loud and the bonding too clinical to actually make you a believer too, like the protagonists who forget fun in Fiji for family.

This may be the third film in the successful Underworld franchise, but thematically, it is a prequel that goes back 1000 years to trace the rebellion of the lycans -- a hybrid species of werewolves and humans -- against the ruling vampires.

More importantly, the film features Kate Beckinsale, the brand ambassador of the series, in just a fleeting moment in the end. But, you don't really miss her, for there is the feisty Sonja (Rhona Mitra) and her burning passion for enslaved lycan hero, Lucian (Michael Sheen) that stirs a cauldron of revolt against her despotic dad, Viktor, the Vampire (Bill Nighy).

Viktor takes pity on the newborn lycan, Lucian and doesn't kill him despite prophecy forewarning him against the rise of the species. He however enslaves him and keeps him chained with a collar that prevents him from turning into a destructive werewolf. Moreover, he uses his blood to create a whole mixed breed of slaves that protect the vampire kingdom and keep the werewolves at bay. But Lucian grows up to be a dashing hunk, coveted by none other than the Emperor's daughter, Sonja. And it is this forbidden love, unfolding in the moonlight, that forces Lucian to lead a bloody revolt against the tyrannical ruler who is willing to sacrifice his daughter too in this inter-species war.

Watch the film for its special effects and its cinematography which lends an eerie, grey chill to the high-voltage action sequences between weird creatures.

The film has been branded as being ill-timed, since it serenades the spirit of conspicuous consumption in an age of recession. On the contrary, it's just perfect for today's economic gloom-doom scenario, since the film actually spoofs the act of overspending and raises some healthy laughs against gluttony and greed. So, for all you Gucci-Versace guzzlers, this one's a gentle reminder that life's much more than a closet spilling over with meaningless baubles.

Shopaholic Rebecca Bloomwood is just out of college and dreams of becoming a fashion reporter. Because fashion is something she understands and clutters her life with, having being empowered with all the plastic money she can lay her hands on. But when the lady with long legs fills the only vacant spot in the fashion mag, a desperate Rebecca lands up in the oddest of jobs. She becomes the Girl With The Green Scarf: a columnist in a financial magazine that serenades the spirit of saving and thrift. Spendthrift Rebecca is supposed to advice her readers on how not to spend. Not an easy task, specially since her dishy boss (Hugh Dancy) wants her to accompany him to all the boring seminars and meets on APRs and interest rates. And the columnist herself can barely keep herself away from the umpteen malls and their minute-to-minute sales.

Watch the film for a zany comic act by Isla Fisher who almost perfects the role of the ditzy chick who ain't as dumb as you think.

This is essentially a more serious version of Sex and the City, where the protagonists are younger, their concerns are more real and their journey towards self-realisation is likely to strike a deeper chord.

The film carries forward the breezy tale of growing up and understanding the world on the part of four girl friends, which first won applause in 2005. Then, the four friends -- Lenny, Tibby, Carmen and Bridget -- were coping with school daze and decided to stay together always by exchanging a pair of second-hand jeans that mysteriously provided a snug fit to all of them. Here, they are in college and preparing for their summer jobs which would see them not only going different ways, but also slipping on their covenant of staying connected. As the foursome tackle the highs and lows in their lives -- heartbreak, parental angst, pregnancy scares and low self-esteem -- the pair of jeans also gets lost. But it doesn't take long for the friends to realise that a real sisterhood doesn't need extraneous stuff. All it needs is a bit of understanding and loads of love to nurture life-long friendships.

Though the only recognisable star here is America Ferrera, having wowed television viewers with her rendition of Ugly Betty, the film boasts of some fine performances by the other girls too and completely transcends the binds of being a brainless chick flick.

A breezy British comedy, the film is essentially a spoof on life in East Germany before the Wall crumbled. There's a lot of communist-bashing as the all-British Ratcliffe family tries to come to terms with a socio-political system that makes something as innocuous as jiving to Elvis Presley, photographing the scenery or spreading marmalade on toast a heinous crime.

Mrs Ratcliffe (Catherine Tate) tries her best to settle in with her two daughters, after her idealistic husband moves from Yorkshire to East Germany in the 1960s. But smoking cigarettes on the sly doesn't really take her far and soon she ends up brewing a home-made revolution, helping young, disgruntled East Berliners to defect. And when freedom is really threatened, she concocts the mother of all revolutions: it's time for the Ratcliffe family to give the infamous stasi a run for their money and flee too. Savour some zany moments in this laidback chuckle riot.

Ever wondered what Dirty Harry would do post-retirement? The angst-ridden cop would most definitely settle down as a cantankerous senior citizen who would still be trigger-happy. Only this time, he'd pull out his shotgun to keep trespassers off his lawn in a suburban neighbourhood that's increasingly reflecting America's ethnically diverse melting pot culture. And who are the trespassers? Any and everyone who dares to invade the privacy of Walt Kowalski (Clint Eastwood), a sociopath Korean war veteran who can't get along with anyone around him. Neither his sons, his grandsons, his parish priest, his barber. And definitely not with his new Asian neighbours, the Hmong immigrants who are summarily dismissed as chinks and gooks by the racist war veteran, still smarting under some terrible battlefield memories. In this bitter and bleak mindscape, there are only three things that matter to the misanthrope: his faithful Labrador, Daisy, the memory of his dead wife and his vintage car, the 1972 Gran Torino which he assembled at Ford. But that's only until he encounters Thao (Bee Vang) and Sue (ahney Her), the brother-sister duo who live next door. Needless to say, the encounter begins on a fiery note, with Walt pulling out his shotgun to abort Thao's amateur bid to steal his Gran Torino. This was supposed to be Thao's clumsy initiation into the local Hmong gang which is hell bent on enlisting all the new kids on the block. But remember, there's Walt, the all-American repository of the rule of law and the righteous way of life. He not only teaches the young immigrants to stand up for their rights, but ends up learning the lessons of love and tolerance himself.

Clint Eastwood reprises his Million Dollar Baby role as the reluctant mentor and reminds you once again about his commitment to meaningful cinema in commercial Hollywood. Uplifting, topical and absolutely engaging, Gran Torino posits an answer to the current clash-of-cultures theory that seems to have sent the new world in a tizzy.

A biopic based on the life of Petey Greene (Don Cheadle), a convict who became a legendary DJ and TV talk show artist during the historic 60's and early '70s, the film is a compelling story of individual atonement. Petey is discovered behind bars by Radio station executive Dewey Hughes (Chiwetel Ejiofor) when he goes to visit his brother in jail. He gets Petey out on parole and soon makes a star out of the foul-mouthed convict who becomes the prefect host to mirror the fury of the popular uprising and the social discontent that followed the assassination of Martin Luther King in April 1968.

Cheadle puts in a riveting performance as the angry American who wasn't sold out on the American dream.

It's cop land, once more where the LAPD law enforcers battle it out in the crime-ridden streets of LA. But more than the drug peddlars, the pimps and the child molesters, it's an internal war that sees these in-uniform killing machines settling their own scores in the alleys and the malls and cleaning up their own corrupt stables.

Keanu Reeves plays Tom Ludlow, the angry, vodka-guzzling cop who believes he's a one-man army that can clean up the city, by killing the bad guys on the spot. His boss (Forest Whitaker) fondly brands him the department's unguided missile and is determined to protect him at any cost. Even when he is implicated in a fellow officer's murder, Whitaker shields him from the internal sleuth (Hugh Laurie). But Keanu soon realises he isn't the only one needing protection. Mired with corruption, there is an entire list of senior and junior officers who need to be weeded out, before the LAPD can be restored to its pristine glory.

Intelligently paced, with enough thrills to keep the adrenalin pumping, Street Kings unleashes the Keanu charisma after a long time.

The ways of the world are truly strange. You kill a robber and a murderer and you end up being labelled a coward. That's the fate that dogged Robert Ford (Casey Affleck), a young man who joined the gang of famed bandit, Jesse James (Brad Pitt) and ended up killing him, hoping to end a career in crime. But Ford didn't realise that he wasn't the only one who hero worshipped the legend of Missouri. Despite his sundry heists and his infamous crime list which included seventeen murders, Jesse James, the great train robber of the 1880's, was essentially a Robin Hood who loomed larger than life for the commonplace and non-heroic citizens of the wild West.

The film is essentially a biopic of the bandit with a focus on his relationship with his assassin, Ford, who first met him as a star-struck admirer, trying to enlist the similarities between him and his hero. You have blue eyes, I have blue eyes too, he exults, and joins the James gang in its last great heist: the Blue Cut Train Robbery, spearheaded by Jesse and his elder brother, Frank (Sam Shepard). But, it doesn't take long for the young Ford to realise it takes more than a pair of blue eyes to make a balsy hero who could kill without compunction and yet double up as a devoted husband and father and a disciplined celebrity. In a pointed query, Jesse asks his devotee: You want to be like me or you want to be ME? Ford, bogged down by his inadequacies, gradually finds his adulation changing to envy and in a dimly lit parlour, when Jesse has given up his life of crime, he seeks out his fifteen minutes of fame.

It's a long, meandering film which keeps you engrossed with its hard-hitting performances and its intricate eye for detail. While Brad Pitt brings to life the mythical figure, complete, with his majesty and meanness, Casey Affleck is both edgy and unpredictable. But in the final count, it is Roger Deakins breathtaking cinematography which leaves you spellbound with its compelling frames of the expansive planes of the untamed West.

The highlight of the film is a truly Oscar-deserving performance by Kate Winslet as Hanna Schmitz, a Nazi guard at Auschwitz who was responsible for the death of 300 Jews during the second World War. But more than this, the film is important for the controversial question it raises: Was Hanna truly a monster or a victim of circumstance? Does she, and several like her, deserve forgiveness or must they never be absolved of their sins? In a pointed query, during her inquistion, Hanna asks her inquisitor: I was just a guard doing my duty. What would you have done in my position? The prosecutor maintains a strange silence.

For any and every one who's ever nurtured a dream and never been able to find the nerve to fulfil it, Revolutionary Road might be that one last chance to fly before the horizon disappears. And for any and every one who feels there's more to life than pushing files, selling stuff, making money, maintaining an upmarket lifestyle, Revolutionary Road is a wake-up call to break free. Or else, it's gonna be a tryst with ''hopeless emptiness'': the truth that flayed the golden couple -- Frank and April Wheeler -- apart and turned their dream into a nightmare.

Sam Mendes returns to the American dream once again, after ripping it apart in that classic, American Beauty. Here too, he mercifully dissects the sunshine that streams through the happy Wheeler home in the glorious 1950s to reveal the cobwebs in the closet. Frank (Leonardo) and April (Kate) have earned the title of the happiest couple that lives on Revolutionary Road, a kind of sunset boulevard in Connecticut where America's upper middle class prospered. With two kids and a lot of love filtering through their home, it would seem like a fairy tale, if only Frank didn't feel he was doing nothing with his life and April didn't believe they were a special couple. The existentially weary couple decides to chuck their middle class boredom and move to Paris for a more meaningful life, where April would work and Frank would take time off, to follow his dreams. But hey! Society doesn't function that way, does it. Revolutionary lifestyles are meant only for the unrealistic, unstable beatniks, aren't they.

That's the bitter truth the couple is forced to realise, as Frank gets sucked deeper into his job and April is forced to carry on as the housewife heroine...for the sake of family, propriety, security and social norms. Unless, she wilfully turns her back to the bourgeois life. A powerful film, marked by powerpacked performances, this is almost a coming-of-age for Hollywood's most successful romantic couple that reunites a decade after Titanic. See what happens to Jack Dawson and Rose Bukater in a real world, in case they had survived the ship wreck.

Mike wants to become a world class boxer, but fails to make it in the Berlin ring. He returns home, much to the disgruntlement of his sister Anna, and enters the ugly, brutal world of illegal street boxing, where death is the final whistle.

Is Mike ready for this brand of violence? Can he rain his sledgehammer blows on his best buddy? Does money justify a dehumanised life? Out of Bounds has won requisite applause at sundry international film festivals for addressing these questions with style and sensitivity.

It's hard to believe that this film has been directed by Roland Joffe who created classics like The Killing Fields and The Mission. Indeed, it's a shoddy piece of cinema that offers almost nothing.

A top model is abducted by an unseen, unknown offender and held in captivity for days on end. Soon, she finds a co-hostage and ends up falling into his arms, hoping to find a way to escape the unseen beast who uses the most gruesome methods to torture his victims. Like burning their face with acid or soaking them with the blood of their pet dogs.

Truly, stomach churning stuff, meant only for those with a yen for the macabre.

This must be the first Iraqi film to hit the headlines after the fall of Saddam Hussain. And what an impact! The film also must be one of the strongest anti-war statements, after Schindler's List and No Man's Land. With its mesmerising cast of child actors, Turtles Can Fly, literally makes you cringe with horror and cry out in dismay, as you try and keep pace with this bunch of kids who must survive the rigours of a Kurdish refugee camp on the Iraq-Turkey border in 2003, just before the US invasion of Iraq.

They call him Satellite, a young boy who is not only the unofficial leader of the group of children in the camp, but is also indispensable for the elders. Being smart and resourceful, he manages to fix a satellite in the camp, enabling the people to watch the turn of events, as they wait for the US war against terror to commence. But Satellite has other arduous duties too. He must command his little troops into the neighbouring fields which need to be cleared of mines. Something his army of young kids is adept at, despite having lost their limbs in the operation. The arrival of three mysterious kids -- the limbless, clairvoyant Henkov, his beautiful sister, Agrin and a blind toddler -- completely changes young Satellite's life, even as he tries to come to terms with the tortured past of the three new arrivals.

Is there hope at the end of the road for these innocent victims? The Americans come, but to no avail. For they have nothing to offer to these bruised, battered souls who have been forced to bear the brunt of history. The film leaves you devastated with its chilling climax and shakes you out of your stupor, even as it overawes you with its powerful imagery of the wasteland that is war. Don't miss it..

The stories of the Holocaust continue....To shock and awe. This time, it's a tale of three prisoners who suffered the brutalities of World War ll and managed to survive, albeit with scars that even time failed to erase. As Christopher Plummer, confessing how difficult it has been living with wife, Susan Sarandon, a holocaust survivor, says: They're all here in the attic, the six million Jews, the victims of Pol Pot, the killing fields...they all live in my house!
Yes, Sarandon, an American, spent her girlhood in the transit camp of Drancy on the outskirts of Paris, where Jews were detained by the Vichy government before being sent to Auschwitz. And she could never put the experience behind, despite the pill-popping, the counselling sessions, the dose of extra kindness by friends and family. Nor could she forget her two companions who stood by her in those turbulent times: Jakob (Max von Sydow) who saved her life and mentored her through the near-death experience and Christopher (Gabriel Byrne) who followed her like a little lamb and wore his heart on his sleeve for her. Now, several years later, the trio meet again in Sarandon's idyllic farm on the banks of a sylvan lake in Quebec and the past threatens to cast its ominous shadow over the peaceful present. Jakob, after years of ill-treatment, seems to be living on the edge and has given up his writing career. Christopher still burns with the unspent flame he harbours for Sarandon, while Sarandon herself must choose between a devoted husband and her lost love.

It's a tangled web of emotions -- of the past and the present -- which unfolds on a family dinner, where it takes more than the rain to wash off the scabs of history. Watch it for the unresolved equations -- and questions -- that must definitely mar the life of any and every one who survives a violent act of history, and for a gripping performance by the stalwarts from Hollywood: Sarandon, Plummer, von Sydow.

Imagine if life begins backwards. The emotional emptiness, the loneliness, the mental and physical debilitation precedes the innocence, the physical well-being, the emotional exuberance of childhood. Would the experience of living then, be more wholesome?

David Fincher raises some pertinent philosophical questions in this gentle, meditative film about loving and living in a world where chaos rules and impermanence is the norm. Based on a story by F Scott Fitzgerald, the film is essentially a fantasy that recreates the flavour of Forrest Gump. Like Gump, Benjamin Button too doesn't merely live a life. He passes through an age in the history of the world and his reflections serve as a mirror to the events that shaped it. Born as an old man, just before the first World War in New Orleans, Benjamin grows up as an abandoned kid in an old people's home, looking up to kind old Queenie (Taraji P Henson) as his momma. As time passes, Benjamin not only grows younger, but also manages to find love and have a family, even if the happiness is destined to be short lived. His childhood friend Daisy (Cate Blanchett) grows up to be his beloved, with the two being at the same stage of life, just for a few years. For Daisy's growing old, while Benjamin's progressing towards infancy.

It's a long, lingering, languorously told love story that traverses almost a whole century and ends in 2005, while Hurricane Katrina is battering Louisiana into pulp. The romance unfolds through the pages of Benjamin's diary which is being read aloud by his daughter, Julia Ormond, to her dying mother, Daisy.

The film has an artistic canvas, which creates the period pieces with exquisite panache. Of course, equally enthralling is the make-up which almost transforms Pitt as he passes from an ugly geriatric to a dashing young man. Watch the film for it's curious flavour.
